{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2011}} {{Distinguish|Travesti|Travesty (disambiguation)}} [[File:Bernhardt Hamlet2.jpg|thumb|220px|right|[[Sarah Bernhardt]] as [[Hamlet]]]]
'''''Travesti''''' (literally "disguised" in French) is a theatrical term referring to the portrayal of a character in an [[opera]], [[Play (theatre)|play]], or [[ballet]] by a performer of the opposite sex. Depending on sources, the term may be given as '''travesty''',<ref>*Budden, Julian (1992), 'Travesty' in ''The [[New Grove Dictionary of Opera]]'', p 799</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Anne Hermann|title=Travesty and Transgression: Transvestism in Shakespeare, Brecht, and Churchill|journal=Theatre Journal|year=1989|volume=41|issue=2|pages=133–154|doi=10.2307/3207855|url=http://jstor.org/stable/3207855|publisher=The Johns Hopkins University Press}}</ref> '''''travesti''''',<ref>[[Michael Kennedy (music critic)|Kennedy, Michael]] (2006), ''The Oxford Dictionary of Music'', p 899</ref><ref>*Warrack, John and West, Ewan (1992), ''The Oxford Dictionary of Opera'', p 716</ref> or '''''en travesti'''''. The ''Oxford Essential Dictionary of Foreign Terms in English'' explains the origin of the latter term as "pseudo-[[French language|French]]",<ref>According to Speake and LaFlaur (1999), the phrase itself is not recorded in French, and derives from the misinterpretation of ''travesti'' (the [[past participle]] of the French verb ''travestir'') as a noun.</ref> although French sources from the mid-19th century have used the term, e.g. ''Bibliothèque musicale du Théâtre de l'opéra'' (1876), ''La revue des deux mondes '' (1868), and have continued the practice into the 21st century.<ref>See, for example Duron (2008) p. 231 and Coste (2004) pp. 26 and 141</ref>
For social reasons, female roles were played by boys or men in many early forms of theatre, and ''travesti'' roles continued to be used in several types of context even after actresses became accepted on the stage. The popular British theatrical form of the [[pantomime]] traditionally contains a role for a "[[principal boy]]", a [[breeches role]] played by a young woman, and also one or more [[pantomime dame]]s, female comic roles played by men. Similarly, in the formerly popular genre of [[Victorian burlesque]], there were usually one or more breeches roles.
==Men in female roles== [[File:Farinelli female caricature edited.jpg|thumb|170 px|left|The famous castrato [[Farinelli]] caricatured in one of his female roles]] Until the late 17th century in England and the early 19th century in the [[Papal States]]—although not elsewhere in Europe—women were conventionally portrayed by male actors (usually adolescents) in [[drag (clothing)|drag]] because the presence of actual women on stage was considered immoral.
===In theatre=== As a [[boy player]], [[Alexander Cooke]] is thought to have created many of Shakespeare's principal female roles, as well as [[Agrippina the Elder|Agrippina]] in [[Ben Jonson]]'s ''[[Sejanus His Fall]]''.<ref>[[F. E. Halliday]], ''A Shakespeare Companion 1564-1964'', Baltimore, Penguin, 1964; pp. 114-15.</ref> With the [[Restoration (England)|Restoration of the monarchy]] in 1660, women began to appear on the English stage, although some female roles continued to be played by boys and young men, including romantic leads. [[Edward Kynaston]], whose roles included the title role in Ben Jonson's ''[[Epicoene, or the Silent Woman|Epicoene]]'' and Evadne in [[Francis Beaumont|Beaumont]] and [[John Fletcher (playwright)|Fletcher's]] ''[[The Maid's Tragedy]]'', was one of the last of the era's boy players.<ref>Howe (1992) p. 25.</ref>
London's [[Shakespeare's Globe]] theatre, a modern reconstruction of the original [[Globe Theatre]], continues the practice of casting men in female Shakespearean roles. Toby Cockerell played Katherine of France in the theatre's opening production of ''[[Henry V (play)|Henry V]]'' in 1997,<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/audience-plays-its-part-in-shakespeares-wooden-o-1254497.html "Audience plays its part in Shakespeare's wooden O"]. ''[[The Independent]]'', 7 June 1997</ref> while [[Mark Rylance]] played Cleopatra in the 1999 production of ''[[Antony and Cleopatra]]''.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/264171.stm "Meet Mr Cleopatra"]. [[BBC News]], 27 January 1999</ref>
''Travesti'' roles for men are still to be found in British [[pantomime]], where there is at least one humorous (and usually older) female character traditionally played by a male actor, the [[pantomime dame]].<ref>See, e.g., [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml?xml=/arts/2005/12/14/btpanto14.xml&sSheet=/arts/2005/12/14/ixartleft.html "Panto's merriest widow"]. ''The Telegraph'', 14 December 2005, accessed 7 February 2011</ref>
===In opera=== [[Castrato|Castrati]], adult males with a female singing voice (usually produced by castration before puberty), appeared in the earliest operas – initially in female roles. In the first performance of [[Monteverdi]]'s ''[[L'Orfeo|Orfeo]]'' in 1607 the roles of [[Eurydice]] and [[Proserpina]] were both sung by castrati. However, by 1680 the castrati had become the predominant singers for leading male roles as well. The use of castrati for both male and female roles was particularly strong in the [[Papal States]], where women were forbidden from public stage performances until the 19th century.
An exception to this practice was in 17th and 18th century French opera where it was traditional to use uncastrated male voices both for the hero and for malevolent female divinities and spirits.<ref>Senelick (2000) p. 177</ref> In [[Jean-Baptiste Lully|Lully]]'s 1686 opera ''[[Armide (Lully)|Armide]]'' the hero (Renaud) was sung by a [[haute-contre]] (a type of high [[tenor]] voice) while the female spirit of hatred (La Haine) was sung by a tenor. In [[Rameau]]'s 1733 ''[[Hippolyte et Aricie]]'', the hero ([[Hippolytus (mythology)|Hippolyte]]) was sung by an haute-contre, while the roles of the three [[Parcae|Fates]] and [[Tisiphone]] were scored for [[bass (voice type)|basses]] and tenors. The remaining female roles in both operas were sung by women. The title role of the vain but ugly marsh nymph in Rameau's ''[[Platée]]'' is also for an haute-contre.
Female roles in opera sung by men can still be found, although they are not common. The role of the witch in [[Engelbert Humperdinck (composer)|Humperdinck]]'s 1890 opera ''[[Hänsel und Gretel (opera)|Hänsel und Gretel]]'' was originally written for a [[mezzo-soprano]], but was sung by the tenor [[Philip Langridge]] in the [[Metropolitan Opera]]'s 2009 production directed by [[Richard Jones (director)|Richard Jones]].<ref>[[Metropolitan Opera]] (2009). [http://www.metoperafamily.org/metopera/news/interviews/detail.aspx?id=10678 "Sweet and Low-Down"]</ref> [[Azio Corghi]]'s 2005 opera ''Il dissoluto assolto'', which incorporates story elements from Mozart's ''[[Don Giovanni]]'', casts a [[counter-tenor]] in the role of the [[mannequin]] of Donna Elvira.<ref>Moiraghi, p. 324</ref>
===In dance=== The portrayal of women by male dancers was very common in [[Renaissance]] court ballet<ref>Lee (2202) p. 54</ref> and has continued into more modern times, although primarily restricted to comic or malevolent female characters. The use of male dancers for all the female roles in a ballet persisted well into the 18th century in the Papal States, when women dancers had long been taking these roles elsewhere in Italy. Abbé Jérôme Richard who travelled to Rome in 1762 wrote: "Female Dancers are not permitted on the stages in Rome. They substitute for them boys dressed as women and there is also a police ordinance that decreed they wear black bloomers."<ref name = "HW38">quoted in Harris-Warrick (2005) p. 38</ref> Another French traveller that year, Joseph-Thomas, comte d'Espinchal, asked himself: "What impression can one have of ballet in which the prima ballerina is a young man in disguise with artificial feminine curves?"<ref name = "HW38" />
In the original production of ''[[The Sleeping Beauty (ballet)|The Sleeping Beauty]]'' in 1890, a male dancer, [[Enrico Cecchetti]], created the role of the evil fairy Carabosse, although the role has subsequently been danced by both men and women.<ref>Brillarelli (1995) p. 31.</ref>
In [[Frederick Ashton]]'s 1948 choreography of ''[[Cinderella (Ashton)|Cinderella]]'', [[Robert Helpmann]] and Ashton himself danced the roles of the two stepsisters. [[Ben Stevenson (dancer)|Ben Stevenson]] later continued the practice of casting male dancers as the stepsisters in his own choreography of the ballet.<ref>Upper (2004) p. 66</ref> Other female ballet characters traditionally performed by male dancers are Old Madge, the village sorceress in ''[[La Sylphide]]'' and the Widow Simone in ''[[La fille mal gardée]]''.
==Women in male roles== [[File:Eugénie Fiocre as a matador.jpg|thumb|180 px|The ballerina [[Eugénie Fiocre]] as a [[matador]] circa 1860]] With the [[English Restoration|Restoration of Charles II]] in 1660 women started appearing on the English stage, both in the female roles that in Shakespeare's day had been portrayed by men and boys, and in male roles. It has been estimated that of the 375 plays produced in London between 1660 and 1700, nearly a quarter contained one or more roles for actresses dressed as men.<ref>See Howe (1992)</ref> Amongst the 19th century actresses who made a mark in ''travesti'' roles were [[Mary Anne Keeley]] who portrayed Smike in the stage adaptation of ''[[Nicholas Nickleby]]'' and the robber [[Jack Sheppard]] in [[John Baldwin Buckstone|Buckstone]]'s play based on his life; [[Maude Adams]] who played [[Peter and Wendy|Peter Pan]] in the American premiere of [[J. M. Barrie|Barrie]]'s play and went on to play the role over 1,500 times;<ref>Harbin, Marra, and Schanke (2005) p. 15</ref> and [[Sarah Bernhardt]] who created the role of [[Napoleon II of France]] in [[Edmond Rostand]]'s ''[[L'Aiglon]]'', played [[Lorenzino de' Medici]] in [[Alfred de Musset|Musset]]'s ''Lorenzaccio'', Pelléas in [[Maurice Maeterlinck|Maeterlinck]]'s ''[[Pelléas and Mélisande]]'' and perhaps most famously played the title role in ''[[Hamlet]]''. In the [[Victorian era]], [[Victorian burlesque|musical burlesques]] generally included several breeches roles. According to the ''[[Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians]]'', although "an almost indispensable element of burlesque was the display of attractive women dressed in tights, often in travesty roles ... the plays themselves did not normally tend to indecency."<ref>[[Erich Schwandt|Schwandt, Erich]] et al. [http://www.oxfordmusiconline.com/subscriber/article/grove/music/04381 "Burlesque",] ''Grove Music Online''. Oxford Music Online, accessed 3 February 2011 {{subscription}}</ref> One of the specialists in these roles was [[Nellie Farren]] who created the title roles in numerous burlesques and pantomimes, including ''[[Robert the Devil (Gilbert)|Robert the Devil]]'', ''[[Little Jack Sheppard]]'' and ''[[Ruy Blas and the Blasé Roué]]''.<ref>Culme, John. [http://www.gabrielleray.150m.com/ArchiveTextF/NellieFarren.html Information "Nellie Farren (1848-1904) English burlesque actress"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091012233616/http://www.gabrielleray.150m.com/ArchiveTextF/NellieFarren.html |date=12 October 2009 }} at Footlight Notes, 2003, accessed 8 February 2011</ref> In British [[pantomime]], which is still regularly performed, the young male protagonist or [[Principal boy]] is traditionally played by an actress in boy's clothes.<ref>Taylor (2007) pp. 117 and ''passim''</ref>
The practice of women performing ''en travesti'' in operas became increasingly common in the early 19th century as [[castrato]] singers went out of fashion and were replaced by [[mezzo-soprano]]s or [[contralto]]s in the young masculine roles. For example, the title role of [[Gioachino Rossini|Rossini]]'s 1813 ''[[Tancredi]]'' was specifically written for a female singer. However, ''travesti'' mezzo-sopranos had been used earlier by both [[George Frideric Handel|Handel]] and [[Mozart]], sometimes because a castrato was not available, or to portray a boy or very young man, such as Cherubino in ''[[The Marriage of Figaro]]''. In 20th-century opera, composers continued to use women to sing the roles of young men, when they felt the mature tenor voice sounded wrong for the part. One notable example was [[Richard Strauss]], who used a mezzo-soprano for Octavian in ''[[Der Rosenkavalier]]'' and the Composer in ''[[Ariadne auf Naxos]]''.
From 1830 to 1850, female ballet dancers were increasingly seen in the ''[[corps de ballet]]'' portraying [[matador]]s, [[hussar]]s, and cavaliers, and even as the [[prima ballerina]]'s 'leading man', a practice which was to last well into the 20th century in France.<ref>Garafola (1985) p. 35.</ref> Although both [[Fanny Elssler]] and her sister Thérèse danced ''travesti'' roles at the Paris Opera, Thérèse, who was very tall by the standards of the day, danced them more frequently, often partnering Fanny as her leading man.<ref>Foster (1998) p. 221</ref> The French ballerina [[Eugénie Fiocre]], who created the role of Franz in ''[[Coppélia]]'', was particularly known for her ''travesti'' performances.<ref>Anderson (1992) p. 257</ref>

The '''Trump–Russia dossier''', also known as the '''Steele dossier''',<ref name="Vogel_Haberman_10/27/2017"/> is a [[Private intelligence agency|private intelligence]] report comprising memos written between June and December 2016 by [[Christopher Steele]],<ref name="Shane_Confessore_Rosenberg_1/12/2017"/> a former head of the Russia Desk for [[Secret Intelligence Service|British intelligence]] (MI6). The resulting dossier contains allegations of misconduct and conspiracy between [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|Donald Trump's presidential campaign]] and the [[Government of Russia]] during the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 election]], with campaign members and Russian operatives allegedly colluding to [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections|interfere in the election]] to benefit Trump.<ref name="Sumter_11/16/2017"/> It also alleged that Russia sought to damage [[Hillary Clinton]]'s candidacy, including sharing negative information about Clinton with the Trump campaign.<ref name="Sipher_1/11/2018"/> The dossier was published in full by [[BuzzFeed]] on January 10, 2017.<ref name="Bensinger_1/10/2017">{{cite web | last=Bensinger | first=Ken | last2=Elder | first2=Miriam | last3=Schoofs | first3=Mark | title=These Reports Allege Trump Has Deep Ties To Russia | website=[[BuzzFeed]] | date=January 10, 2017 | url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/kenbensinger/these-reports-allege-trump-has-deep-ties-to-russia | accessdate=December 24, 2017}}</ref> Several mainstream media outlets criticized BuzzFeed's decision to release it without verifying its allegations.<ref name="Bump_1/11/2017">{{cite web |last1=Bump |first1=Philip |title=BuzzFeed, the Russia dossier and the problem of too much information |date=January 11, 2017 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2017/01/11/the-problem-of-too-much-information/ |work=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=July 29, 2017}}</ref><ref name= "Zurawik_1/11/2017">{{cite web |last1=Zurawik |first1=David |title=BuzzFeed undermines all journalists with Trump 'dossier' |date=January 11, 2017 |accessdate=January 10, 2018 |url=https://www.baltimoresun.com/entertainment/tv/z-on-tv-blog/bal-buzzfeed--trump-dossier-journalism-debased-20170111-story.html |work=[[The Baltimore Sun]]}}</ref>
<!-- History and funding--> In October 2015, private investigative firm [[Fusion GPS]] was contracted by conservative political website ''[[The Washington Free Beacon]]'' to provide political [[opposition research]] against Trump. In April 2016, attorney [[Marc Elias]] separately hired Fusion GPS to investigate Trump on behalf of [[Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, 2016|Hillary Clinton's campaign]] and the [[Democratic National Committee|DNC]]. The ''Free Beacon'' stopped their backing when Trump became the presumptive [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] presidential nominee.<ref name="Shane_Confessore_Rosenberg_1/12/2017"/> In June 2016, Fusion GPS subcontracted Steele's firm to compile the dossier. His instructions were to seek answers to why Trump would "repeatedly seek to do deals in a [[Russia|notoriously corrupt police state]]".<ref name="Simpson_Fritsch_1/2/2018"/> Clinton campaign officials were reportedly unaware that Fusion GPS had subcontracted Steele, and he was not told the Clinton campaign was the recipient of his research.<ref name="Entous_Barrett_Helderman_10/24/2017"/><ref name="Mayer_3/12/2018"/> Following Trump's election as president, funding from Clinton and the DNC ceased, but Steele continued his research and was reportedly paid directly by Fusion GPS co-founder [[Glenn R. Simpson]].<ref name="Sampathkumar_8/23/2017"/> The completed dossier was then handed to British and American intelligence services.<ref name="Perez_Prokupecz_Raju_4/18/2017"/>
<!--Reception and veracity--> The media, the [[United States Intelligence Community|intelligence community]], and most experts have treated the dossier with caution due to its unverified assertions, while Trump has denounced the report as [[fake news]].<ref name"Sengupta_4/20/2018">{{cite web | last=Sengupta | first=Kim | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/trump-russia-dossier-christopher-steele-fake-true-mi6-putin-moscow-hotel-cohen-a8315046.html | title=Steele dossier: Donald Trump denounced the document as fake, but much of its contents have turned out to be true | website=[[The Independent]] | date=April 20, 2018 | accessdate=August 19, 2018}}</ref> However, the intelligence community takes the allegations seriously and is investigating them.<ref name="Chait_12/7/2017"/><ref name="Tracy_1/11/2017"/><ref name="Hennessey_Wittes_1/12/2017"/><ref name="Harding_Hopkins_1/12/2017"/>
In May 2018, former career intelligence officer [[James Clapper]] stated that "more and more" of the dossier had been validated over time.<ref name="Bowden_5/26/2018"/> Overall, while some allegations of the dossier have been corroborated,<ref name="Sciutto_Perez_2/10/2017">{{cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2017/02/10/politics/russia-dossier-update/index.html|title=US investigators corroborate some aspects of the Russia dossier|last1=Sciutto|first1=Jim|authorlink1=Jim Sciutto|last2=Perez|first2=Evan|date=February 10, 2017|website=[[CNN]]|accessdate=February 10, 2017}}</ref> others remain unverified.<ref name="Lee_12/26/2017">{{cite news |last=Lee |first=Michelle Ye Hee |title=Trump slams FBI, Obamacare in post-Christmas tweets |date=December 26, 2017 |accessdate=January 11, 2018 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-slams-fbi-obamacare-in-post-christmas-tweets/2017/12/26/6f77f684-ea4c-11e7-9f92-10a2203f6c8d_story.html |quote=Officials have said some of the information it contains has been corroborated, but other parts—including the most salacious claims about Trump's behavior—remain unverified.}}</ref> Some may require access to classified information for verification.<ref name="Berke_6/8/2017">{{cite web | last=Berke | first=Jeremy | title=Comey's cryptic answer about the infamous Trump dossier makes it look likely it could be verified | website=[[Business Insider]] | date=June 8, 2017 | url=https://www.businessinsider.com/comey-steele-trump-russia-dossier-will-be-verified-2017-6 | access-date=January 23, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Truscott_8/18/2018">{{cite web | last=Truscott IV | first=Lucian K. | date=August 18, 2018 | title=The people on Trump's list aren't enemies, they are witnesses. The secrets they have aren't secrets anymore. They're evidence | website=[[Salon (website)|Salon]] | url=https://www.salon.com/2018/08/18/the-people-on-trumps-list-arent-enemies-they-are-witnesses/ | accessdate=August 18, 2018 }}</ref>
==History==
The [[opposition research]] conducted by [[Fusion GPS]] on Donald Trump was completed in two phases with separate funders. The first research phase, from October 2015 to May 2016, was funded by ''[[The Washington Free Beacon]]''. The second phase, from June 2016 to December 2016, was separate from the ''Washington Free Beacon'' request and was funded by the [[Democratic National Committee|DNC]] and the [[Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, 2016|Clinton campaign]]. Only the second phase produced the dossier.<ref name="Borger_1/11/2017"/><ref name="Lima_10/27/2017">{{cite web | last=Lima | first=Cristiano | title=Conservative Free Beacon originally funded firm that created Trump-Russia dossier | website=[[Politico]] | date=October 27, 2017 | url=https://politi.co/2iDXLp9 | access-date=February 11, 2018}}</ref>
=== Research funded by conservative website ===
In October 2015, before the official start of the [[Republican Party presidential primaries, 2016|2016 Republican primary campaign]], ''[[The Washington Free Beacon]]'', an American [[Conservatism in the United States|conservative]] [[political journalism]] website primarily funded by Republican donor [[Paul Singer (businessman)|Paul Singer]], hired the American research firm Fusion GPS to conduct general opposition research on Trump and other Republican presidential candidates.<ref name="Vogel_Haberman_10/27/2017">{{cite news |first=Kenneth P. |last=Vogel |authorlink= Kenneth Vogel |first2=Maggie |last2=Haberman |authorlink2= Maggie Haberman |title=Conservative Website First Funded Anti-Trump Research by Firm That Later Produced Dossier |date=October 27, 2017 |website=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/27/us/politics/trump-dossier-paul-singer.html | access-date=April 1, 2018 }}</ref> The ''Free Beacon'' and Singer were "part of the conservative never-Trump movement".<ref name="Isikoff_Corn_3/17/2018"/> For months, Fusion GPS gathered information about Trump, focusing on his business and entertainment activities. When Trump became the presumptive nominee on May 3, 2016,<ref name="Johnson_5/4/2016">{{cite web | last=Johnson | first=Jenna | title=The night Donald Trump became the presumptive nominee | website=[[The Washington Post]] | date=May 4, 2016 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2016/05/04/the-night-donald-trump-became-the-presumptive-nominee/ | access-date=April 10, 2018}}</ref> ''The Free Beacon'' stopped funding research on him.<ref name="Shane_Confessore_Rosenberg_1/12/2017">{{cite news | last=Shane | first=Scott | last2=Confessore | first2=Nicholas | last3=Rosenberg | first3=Matthew | title=How a Sensational, Unverified Dossier Became a Crisis for Donald Trump | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=January 12, 2017 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/11/us/politics/donald-trump-russia-intelligence.html | access-date=February 11, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Borger_1/12/2017">{{cite web | last=Borger | first=Julian | title=How the Trump dossier came to light: secret sources, a retired spy and John McCain | website=[[The Guardian]] | date=January 12, 2017 | url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jan/11/trump-russia-report-opposition-research-john-mccain | access-date=February 11, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Robertson_2/7/2018">{{cite web | last=Robertson | first=Lori | title=Q&A on the Nunes Memo | website=[[FactCheck.org]] | date=February 7, 2018 | url=https://www.factcheck.org/2018/02/qa-nunes-memo/ | access-date=February 12, 2018}}</ref>
In October 2017, the ''Free Beacon'' issued a statement: {{quote|"All of the work that Fusion GPS provided to the ''Free Beacon'' was based on public sources, and none of the work product that the ''Free Beacon'' received appears in the Steele dossier. The ''Free Beacon'' had no knowledge of or connection to the Steele dossier, did not pay for the dossier, and never had contact with, knowledge of, or provided payment for any work performed by Christopher Steele. Nor did we have any knowledge of the relationship between Fusion GPS and the Democratic National Committee, Perkins Coie, and the Clinton campaign."<ref name="Continetti_Goldfarb_10/27/2017">{{cite web |last1=Continetti |first1=Matthew |last2=Goldfarb |first2=Michael |title=Fusion GPS and the Washington Free Beacon |url=https://freebeacon.com/uncategorized/fusion-gps-washington-free-beacon/ |website=[[The Washington Free Beacon]] |date=October 27, 2017 |accessdate=February 25, 2018 }}</ref>}}
Although the source of the Steele dossier's funding had already been reported correctly over a year before,<ref name="Shane_Confessore_Rosenberg_1/12/2017"/><ref name="Borger_1/12/2017"/><ref name="Robertson_2/7/2018"/> and alluded to by the ''Free Beacon'' in October 2017,<ref name="Continetti_Goldfarb_10/27/2017"/> a February 2, 2018, story by the [[Associated Press]] (AP) contributed to confusion about its funding by stating that the dossier "was initially funded" by the ''Washington Free Beacon'', so the AP posted a correction the next day: "Though the former spy, Christopher Steele, was hired by a firm that was initially funded by the Washington Free Beacon, he did not begin work on the project until after Democratic groups had begun funding it."<ref name="Tucker_Jalonick_Day_2/3/2018">{{cite web | last1=Tucker | first1=Eric | last2=Jalonick | first2=Clare | last3=Day | first3=Chad | title=Correction: Trump-Russia Probe story | date=February 3, 2018 | website=[[AP News]] | url=https://www.apnews.com/63c883156e314b68b86209d3b63890f5 | access-date=April 15, 2018}}</ref>
=== Research funded by Democrats produces dossier ===
The second phase of opposition research was funded by the [[Democratic National Committee|DNC]] and the [[Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, 2016|Clinton campaign]], working through their attorney of record, [[Marc Elias]] of [[Perkins Coie]].<ref name="Entous_Barrett_Helderman_10/24/2017">{{cite web |last1=Entous |first1=Adam |last2=Barrett |first2=Devlin |last3=Helderman |first3=Rosalind |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/clinton-campaign-dnc-paid-for-research-that-led-to-russia-dossier/2017/10/24/226fabf0-b8e4-11e7-a908-a3470754bbb9_story.html |title=Clinton campaign, DNC paid for research that led to Russia dossier |date=October 24, 2017 |work=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=October 25, 2017}}</ref> In March 2016, Fusion GPS "approached Perkins Coie to see if its clients would be interested in paying Fusion" to continue its existing research on Trump,<ref name="Watkins_Merica_Polantz_10/25/2017">{{cite web | last=Watkins | first=Eli | last2=Merica | first2=Dan | last3=Polantz | first3=Katelyn | title=Clinton campaign, DNC helped fund dossier research | website=[[CNN]] | date=October 25, 2017 | url=https://www.cnn.com/2017/10/24/politics/fusion-gps-clinton-campaign/index.html | access-date=September 9, 2018}}</ref> and in April 2016, Elias hired Fusion GPS to perform opposition research on Trump.<ref name="Entous_Barrett_Helderman_10/24/2017"/><ref name="Watkins_Merica_Polantz_10/25/2017"/>
As part of their investigation, Fusion GPS hired Orbis Business Intelligence, a private British intelligence firm, to look into connections between Trump and Russia. Orbis co-founder [[Christopher Steele]], a retired British [[Secret Intelligence Service|MI6]] officer with expertise in Russian matters,<ref name="Shane_Confessore_Rosenberg_1/12/2017"/> was hired as a subcontractor to do the job.<ref name="Johnson_Kelly_1/9/2018">{{cite web | last1=Johnson | first1=Kevin | last2=Kelly | first2=Erin | title=Dossier author was told FBI had a source inside Trump Organization | website=[[USA Today]] | date=January 9, 2018 | url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2018/01/09/dossier-author-told-fbi-had-source-inside-trump-organization/1017938001/ | access-date=January 10, 2018}}</ref> In total, Perkins Coie paid Fusion GPS $1.02 million in fees and expenses, $168,000 of which was paid to Orbis by Fusion GPS and used by them to produce the dossier.<ref name="Hosenball_11/1/2017">{{cite web |last=Hosenball |first=Mark |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-russia-dossier/ex-british-spy-paid-168000-for-trump-dossier-u-s-firm-discloses-idUSKBN1D15XH |title=Ex-British spy paid $168,000 for Trump dossier, U.S. firm discloses |date=November 1, 2017 |website=[[Reuters]] |accessdate=November 7, 2017}}</ref> The DNC and Clinton campaign disclosed the total amount paid to Perkins Coie on campaign finance reports.<ref name="Johnson_9/10/2018">{{cite web | last=Johnson | first=Ted | title=Omarosa Reveals New Recording of Trump Blaming Hillary Clinton for Collusion | website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | date=September 10, 2018 | url=https://variety.com/2018/politics/news/omarosa-trump-the-view-1202934826/ | access-date=September 11, 2018}}</ref>
Orbis was hired between June and November 2016, and Steele produced 16 memos during that time, with a 17th memo added in December.<ref name="Borger_4/28/2017"/> The memos were like "prepublication notes" based on reports from Steele's sources, and were not released as a fully [[vetting|vetted]] and "finished news article".<ref name="Flegenheimer_1/8/2018">{{cite news | last=Flegenheimer | first=Matt | title=Fusion GPS Founder Hauled From the Shadows for the Russia Election Investigation | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=January 8, 2018 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/08/us/politics/fusion-gps-glenn-simpson.html | access-date=March 25, 2018}}</ref> Steele believes that 70–90% of the dossier is accurate,<ref name="Borger_11/15/2017"/> a view that is shared by Simpson.<ref name="Flegenheimer_1/8/2018"/>
Simpson has stated that, to his knowledge, Steele did not pay any of his sources.<ref name="Raju_Herb_Polantz_11/16/2017">{{cite web | last1=Raju | first1=Manu | last2=Herb | first2=Jeremy | last3=Polantz | first3=Katelyn | date=November 16, 2017 | title=Fusion GPS co-founder: Steele didn't pay sources for dossier on Trump | website=[[CNN]] | url=https://www.cnn.com/2017/11/15/politics/russia-investigation-fusion-gps-glenn-simpson-dossier/index.html | accessdate=November 19, 2017 }}</ref><ref name="Simpson_Fritsch_1/2/2018"/><ref name="Williams_Beavers_1/18/2018">{{cite news | last1=Williams | first1=Katie Bo | last2=Beavers | first2=Olivia | title='Steele dossier' firm suspected Trump-Russia money laundering | url=https://thehill.com/policy/national-security/369654-steele-dossier-firm-suspected-trump-russia-money-laundering | work=The Hill | date=January 18, 2018 | access-date=April 12, 2018}}</ref> According to investigative reporter [[Jane Mayer]] of ''[[The New Yorker]]'', Orbis has a large number of paid "collectors" who "harvest intelligence from a much larger network of unpaid sources, some of whom don't even realize they are being treated as informants […] but money doesn't change hands, because it could risk violating laws against, say, bribing government officials or insider trading. Paying sources might also encourage them to embellish."<ref name="Mayer_3/12/2018"/> According to British journalist [[Luke Harding]], Steele's sources were not new: "They're not people that he kind of discovered yesterday. They are trusted contacts who essentially had proven themselves in other areas."<ref name="NPR.org_11/21/2017">{{cite web | author=NPR | title=Journalist Investigating Trump And Russia Says 'Full Picture Is One Of Collusion' | website=[[NPR]] | date=November 21, 2017 | url=https://www.npr.org/2017/11/21/565654507/journalist-investigating-trump-and-russia-says-full-picture-is-one-of-collusion | access-date=February 17, 2018}}</ref> Howard Blum said that Steele leaned on sources "whose loyalty and information he had bought and paid for over the years".<ref name="Blum_3/30/2017"/>
Steele delivered his reports individually to Fusion GPS as one- to three-page memos.<ref name="Shane_Confessore_Rosenberg_1/12/2017"/> The first memo, dated June 20, 2016, was sent to Washington by courier and hand-delivered to Fusion GPS. The names of the sources were redacted, "providing instead descriptions of them that enabled Fusion to assess their basic credibility."<ref name="Mayer_3/12/2018"/>
Luke Harding wrote:
{{quote|"At first, obtaining intelligence from Moscow went well. For around six months – during the first half of the year – Steele was able to make inquiries in Russia with relative ease. It got harder from late July, as Trump's ties to Russia came under scrutiny. Finally, the lights went out. Amid a Kremlin cover-up, the sources went silent and information channels shut down."<ref name="Harding_11/15/2017"/>}}
Steele has stated that he soon found "troubling information indicating connections between Trump and the Russian government." According to his sources, "there was an established exchange of information between the Trump campaign and the Kremlin of mutual benefit."<ref name="Corn_10/31/2016"/> According to Harding, "Steele was shocked by the extent of collusion his sources were reporting," and told his friends: "For anyone who reads it, this is a life-changing experience."<ref name="Borger_11/15/2017">{{cite web | last=Borger | first=Julian | title=Christopher Steele believes his dossier on Trump-Russia is 70-90% accurate | website=[[The Guardian]] | date=November 15, 2017 | url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/nov/15/christopher-steele-trump-russia-dossier-accurate | access-date=January 22, 2018}}</ref> Steele felt that what he had unearthed "was something of huge significance, way above party politics."<ref name="Blum_3/30/2017">{{cite web | last=Blum | first=Howard | title=How Ex-Spy Christopher Steele Compiled His Explosive Trump-Russia Dossier | website=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]] | date=March 30, 2017 | url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2017/03/how-the-explosive-russian-dossier-was-compiled-christopher-steele | access-date=December 24, 2017}}</ref> American reporter [[Howard Blum]] described Steele's rationale for becoming a [[whistleblower]]: "The greater good trumps all other concerns."<ref name="Blum_3/30/2017"/>
On his own initiative, Steele decided to also pass the information to British and American [[intelligence services]] because he believed the findings were a matter of national security for both countries.<ref name="Levine_1/12/2018"/><ref name="Sengupta_1/13/2017">{{cite web | last=Sengupta | first=Kim | title=Ex-MI6 agent so worried by his Donald Trump discoveries he started working without pay | website=[[The Independent]] | date=January 13, 2017 | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/donald-trump-russia-dossier-file-investigation-hacking-christopher-steele-mi6-a7526901.html | access-date=March 3, 2018}}</ref> According to Simpson's testimony, Steele approached the [[FBI]] because he was concerned that Trump, then a candidate, was being [[blackmail]]ed by Russia,<ref name="Herb_Raju_Cohen_1/10/2018"/> and he became "very concerned about whether this represented a national security threat".<ref name="Levine_1/12/2018"/> When Steele showed his findings to FBI agents in Rome in early July, their reaction was "shock and horror".<ref name="Herb_Raju_Cohen_1/10/2018">{{cite web | last=Herb | first=Jeremy | last2=Raju | first2=Manu | last3=Cohen | first3=Marshall | title=Fusion co-founder: Dossier author feared Trump was being blackmailed | website=[[CNN]] | date=January 10, 2018 | url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/01/09/politics/feinstein-releases-glenn-simpson-transcript/index.html | access-date=January 21, 2018 | quote= Chris said he was very concerned about whether this represented a national security threat and said he wanted to -- he said he thought we were obligated to tell someone in government, in our government about this information," Simpson said. "He thought from his perspective there was an issue -- a security issue about whether a presidential candidate was being blackmailed." }}</ref><ref name="Kessler_1/9/2018">{{cite web | last=Kessler | first=Glenn | title=What you need to know about Christopher Steele, the FBI and the Trump 'dossier' | website=[[The Washington Post]] | date=January 9, 2018 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/fact-checker/wp/2018/01/09/what-you-need-to-know-about-christopher-steele-the-fbi-and-the-dossier/ | access-date=January 22, 2018}}</ref> Jane Mayer reports that the FBI agents "asked Steele about Papadopoulos, and he [Steele] said that he hadn't heard anything about him."<ref name="Mayer_3/12/2018"/>
Nancy LeTourneau, political writer for the ''[[Washington Monthly]]'', said that, according to [[ABC News]],<ref name="Levine_9/18/2018">{{cite web | last=Levine | first=Mike | title=Trump 'dossier' stuck in New York, didn't trigger Russia investigation, sources say | date=September 18, 2018 | website=[[ABC News]] | url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/trump-dossier-stuck-york-trigger-russia-investigation-sources/story?id=57919471 | access-date=October 5, 2018}}</ref> in July 2016, as Steele was compiling the dossier, he sent what he had to "an FBI contact in Rome, who passed it on to an agent in the FBI's New York field office. It sat there until mid-September, when it was finally sent to the counterintelligence team investigating Russia at FBI headquarters in Washington, D.C." She wrote that "while the Steele dossier was languishing in the FBI's New York field office" for two months, according to ''The Washington Post'', CIA Director John Brennan had started an investigation with a secret task force "composed of several dozen analysts and officers from the CIA, the NSA and the FBI". At the same time, he was busy creating his own dossier of material documenting that "Russia was not only attempting to interfere in the 2016 election, they were doing so in order to elect Donald Trump ... [T]he entire intelligence community was on alert about this situation at least two months before [the dossier] became part of the investigation." She also said that the "Steele dossier has so far proven to be fairly accurate".<ref name="LeTourneau_9/19/2018">{{cite web|url=https://washingtonmonthly.com/2018/09/19/trump-should-be-more-worried-about-the-brennan-dossier/|title=Trump should be more worried about the Brennan dossier|last=LeTourneau|first=Nancy|date=September 19, 2018|website=[[Washington Monthly]]|access-date=September 22, 2018}}</ref>
Steele enjoyed a good working reputation "for the knowledge he had developed over nearly 20 years working on Russia-related issues for [[British intelligence]]."<ref name="Hamburger_2/28/2017"/> Knowing this, in October 2016, a few weeks before the election, the FBI agreed to pay him to continue collecting information. However, the subsequent public release of the dossier stopped discussions between Steele and the FBI.<ref name="Hamburger_2/28/2017">{{cite web |last1=Hamburger |first1=Tom |last2=Helderman |first2=Rosalind S. |title=FBI once planned to pay former British spy who authored controversial Trump dossier |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/fbi-once-planned-to-pay-former-british-spy-who-authored-controversial-trump-dossier/2017/02/28/896ab470-facc-11e6-9845-576c69081518_story.html |date=February 28, 2017 |work=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=March 1, 2017}}</ref> Simpson testified that "Steele wasn't paid by the FBI, but was possibly reimbursed for a trip to Rome to meet with FBI officials."<ref name="Robertson_2/7/2018"/><ref name="Kiely_2/27/2018">{{cite web | last=Kiely | first=Eugene | title=Trump's Spin on Democratic Memo | website=[[FactCheck.org]] | date=February 27, 2018 | url=https://www.factcheck.org/2018/02/trumps-spin-democratic-memo/ | access-date=March 3, 2018}}</ref> According to Mayer, Steele "did request compensation for travelling to Rome, but he never received any."<ref name="Mayer_3/12/2018"/>
Simpson later said that "Steele severed his contacts with [the] FBI before the election following public statements by the FBI that it had found no connection between the Trump campaign and Russia and concerns that [the FBI] was being 'manipulated for political ends by the Trump people'."<ref name="Jalonick_1/9/2018">{{cite web | last=Jalonick | first=Mary | title=Democratic report warns of Russian meddling in Europe, US | website=[[The Washington Post]] | date=January 9, 2018 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/federal_government/author-of-trump-dossier-had-concerns-about-russian-blackmail/2018/01/09/a893fce2-f5a0-11e7-9af7-a50bc3300042_story.html | access-date=January 22, 2018 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180123072443/https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/federal_government/author-of-trump-dossier-had-concerns-about-russian-blackmail/2018/01/09/a893fce2-f5a0-11e7-9af7-a50bc3300042_story.html# | archive-date=January 23, 2018 | dead-url=yes | df=mdy-all }}</ref> Steele had become frustrated with the FBI, whom he believed failed to investigate his reports, choosing instead to focus on the [[Hillary Clinton email controversy|investigation into Clinton's emails]]. According to ''[[The Independent]]'', Steele came to believe that there was a "cabal" inside the FBI, particularly its New York field office linked to Trump advisor [[Rudy Giuliani]], because it blocked any attempts to investigate the links between Trump and Russia.<ref name="Sengupta_1/13/2017"/>
==== What the DNC, Clinton campaign, and Steele knew ====
According to Fusion GPS's co-owners, Glenn Simpson and Peter Fritsch, they did not tell Steele who their ultimate clients were, only that Steele was "working for a law firm",<ref name="Mayer_3/12/2018"/> and they "gave him no specific marching orders beyond this basic question: 'Why did Mr. Trump repeatedly seek to do deals in a notoriously corrupt police state that most serious investors shun?'"<ref name="Simpson_Fritsch_1/2/2018"/>
Jane Mayer reported that when the Clinton campaign "indirectly employed" Steele, Elias created a "legal barrier" by acting "as a firewall" between the campaign and Steele. Thus, any details were "protected by attorney-client privilege. Fusion briefed only Elias on the reports. Simpson sent Elias nothing on paper—he was briefed orally."<ref name="Mayer_3/12/2018"/> Only several months after signing the contract with Fusion GPS did Steele learn that the DNC and the Clinton campaign were the ultimate clients.<ref name="Mayer_3/12/2018"/>
A spokesperson for the DNC stated that neither [[Tom Perez]] nor "the new leadership of the DNC were... involved in any decision-making regarding Fusion GPS, nor were they aware that Perkins Coie was working with the organization."<ref name="Watkins_Merica_Polantz_10/25/2017"/> A spokesperson for Perkins Coie stated that the campaign and the DNC were unaware that Fusion GPS "had been hired to conduct the research".<ref name="Vogel_10/24/2017"/> ''The Washington Post'' reported that it is not clear how much of the research Elias received from Fusion GPS he shared with the campaign and the DNC. It is also not clear who in those organizations knew about the roles of Fusion GPS and Steele, but one person "close to the matter" said the organizations were "not informed by the law firm of Fusion GPS's role".<ref name="Entous_Barrett_Helderman_10/24/2017"/> ''The New York Times'' revealed that earlier in 2017, "Mr. Elias had denied that he had possessed the dossier before the election".<ref name="Vogel_10/24/2017">{{cite web | last=Vogel | first=Kenneth P. | title=Clinton Campaign and Democratic Party Helped Pay for Russia Trump Dossier | website=[[The New York Times]] | date=October 24, 2017 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/24/us/politics/clinton-dnc-russia-dossier.html | access-date=September 9, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Watkins_Merica_Polantz_10/25/2017"/>
The firewall was reportedly so effective that even campaign principals [[John Podesta]] and [[Robby Mook]] did not know that Steele was on the Democratic payroll until ''[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]'' reported on the issue on October 31, 2016.<ref name="Mayer_3/12/2018"/> When the ''Mother Jones'' story broke, [[John Podesta]], chairman of the Clinton campaign, said he was "stunned by the news that the FBI had launched a full-blown investigation into Trump, especially one that was informed by research underwritten by the Clinton campaign." Although they knew that Perkins Coie had spent money for opposition research, neither Podesta nor campaign manager [[Robby Mook]] knew that Steele was on the Democratic payroll. Mayer said they both maintain they "didn't read the dossier until BuzzFeed posted it online.<ref name="Mayer_3/12/2018"/> She has also stated that "the Clinton campaign never learned that Christopher Steele was on their payroll until it [the dossier] was in the press."<ref name="NPR_3/6/2018">{{cite web | title=Journalist Charts The 'Bizarre Twists And Turns' Of The Trump-Russia Dossier | website=[[NPR]] | date=March 6, 2018 | url=https://www.npr.org/2018/03/06/591130207/journalist-charts-the-bizarre-twists-and-turns-of-the-trump-russia-dossier | access-date=October 5, 2018}}</ref> Far from a secret campaign weapon, Steele turned out to be a secret kept from the campaign."<ref name="Mayer_3/12/2018"/>
=== Hints of existence ===
Jane Mayer has described how, in "late summer, Fusion set up a series of meetings, at the Tabard Inn, in Washington, between Steele and a handful of national-security reporters.... Despite Steele's generally cool manner, he seemed distraught about the Russians' role in the election." Mayer attended one of the meetings. No news organizations ran any stories about the allegations at that time.<ref name="Mayer_3/12/2018"/>
==== ''Mother Jones'' story ====
By the third quarter of 2016, many news organizations knew about the existence of the dossier, which had been described as an "open secret" among journalists. However, they chose not to publish information that could not be confirmed.<ref name="Shane_Confessore_Rosenberg_1/12/2017"/><ref name="Ember_Grynbaum_1/10/2017">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/10/business/buzzfeed-donald-trump-russia.html |title=BuzzFeed Posts Unverified Claims on Trump, Igniting a Debate |first1=Sydney |last1=Ember |first2=Michael M. |last2=Grynbaum |date=January 10, 2017 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=April 2, 2018}}</ref>
By October 2016, Steele had compiled 33 pages (16 memos), and he then passed on what he had discovered to [[David Corn]], a reporter from ''[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]'' magazine. On October 31, 2016, a week before the election, ''Mother Jones'' reported that a former intelligence officer, whom they did not name, had produced a report based on Russian sources and turned it over to the FBI.<ref name="Corn_10/31/2016">{{cite web | last=Corn | first=David | date=October 31, 2016 | title=A Veteran Spy Has Given the FBI Information Alleging a Russian Operation to Cultivate Donald Trump | website=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]] | url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2016/10/veteran-spy-gave-fbi-info-alleging-russian-operation-cultivate-donald-trump/ | access-date=December 24, 2017 }}</ref> The article disclosed some of the dossier's allegations:
{{quote|"The first memo, based on the former intelligence officer's conversations with Russian sources, noted, "Russian regime has been cultivating, supporting and assisting TRUMP for at least 5 years. Aim, endorsed by PUTIN, has been to encourage splits and divisions in western alliance". It maintained that Trump "and his inner circle have accepted a regular flow of intelligence from the Kremlin, including on his Democratic and other political rivals". It claimed that Russian intelligence had "compromised" Trump during his visits to Moscow and could "blackmail him". It also reported that Russian intelligence had compiled a dossier on Hillary Clinton based on "bugged conversations she had on various visits to Russia and intercepted phone calls." |author = [[David Corn]] |title = "A Veteran Spy Has Given the FBI Information Alleging a Russian Operation to Cultivate Donald Trump" |source = [[Mother Jones (magazine)|''Mother Jones'']] (October 31, 2016)<ref name="Corn_10/31/2016"/> }}{{clear}}
=== Post-election events ===
After Trump's election on November 8, 2016, the Democratic client stopped paying for the investigation, but Steele continued working on the dossier for Fusion GPS.<ref name="Shane_Confessore_Rosenberg_1/12/2017"/> At that time, Simpson "reportedly spent his own money to continue the investigation".<ref name="Sampathkumar_8/23/2017">{{cite web | work=[[The Independent]] | title=Trump–Russia dossier sources revealed to the FBI by Christopher Steele | first=Mythili | last=Sampathkumar | date=August 23, 2017 | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/trump-russia-dossier-sources-christopher-steele-fbi-senate-judiciary-robert-mueller-a7908946.html | access-date=April 1, 2018}}</ref> After the election, Steele's dossier "became one of Washington's worst-kept secrets, and journalists worked to verify the allegations.<ref name="Shane_Confessore_Rosenberg_1/12/2017"/>
On November 18, 2016, U.S. Senator [[John McCain]], who had been informed about the alleged links between the Kremlin and Trump, met with former British ambassador to Moscow [[Andrew Wood (diplomat)|Sir Andrew Wood]] at the [[Halifax International Security Forum]] in Canada. Wood told McCain about the existence of the collected materials about Trump,<ref name="Edwards_1/11/2017">{{cite web | last=Edwards | first=Jim | title=TIMELINE: That Russian Trump blackmail dossier has been making the rounds for months - here is how it finally came to light | website=[[Business Insider]] | date=January 11, 2017 | url=https://www.businessinsider.com/timeline-russia-trump-sex-blackmail-golden-shower-dossier-2017-1 | access-date=April 7, 2018}}</ref> and also vouched for Steele's professionalism and integrity.<ref name="Sengupta_1/12/2017">{{cite web | last=Sengupta | first=Kim | title=Former British ambassador played key role in leaked Trump documents | website=[[The Independent]] | date=January 12, 2017 | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/donald-trump-russia-dossier-leak-sir-andrew-wood-john-mccain-british-ambassador-spy-a7524931.html | access-date=April 7, 2018}}</ref>
According to Simpson's August 22, 2017, testimony to the Senate Judiciary Committee, Steele and [[David J. Kramer]], a longtime McCain aide and former U.S. State Department official working at [[Arizona State University]], met each other at the Halifax forum and discussed the dossier. Kramer told Steele that McCain wanted to "ask questions about it at the FBI. ... All we sort of wanted was for the government to do its job and we were concerned about whether the information that we provided previously had ever, you know, risen to the leadership level of the FBI." Later, "Kramer followed up with Steele".<ref name="Cheney_1/9/2018"/> Steele had agreed with Fusion GPS to deliver a hard copy of all 16 memos to McCain,<ref name="Borger_4/28/2017"/> which McCain received in early December from Kramer.<ref name="Shane_Confessore_Rosenberg_1/12/2017"/> On December 9, McCain met personally with FBI Director [[James Comey]] to pass on the information.<ref name="Edwards_1/11/2017"/><ref name="Borger_1/11/2017"/><ref name="Resnick_5/9/2018">{{cite web | last=Resnick | first=Gideon | title=McCain Defends Giving Trump Dossier to Comey: Duty Demanded I Do It | website=[[The Daily Beast]] | date=May 9, 2018 | url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/mccain-confirms-he-gave-trump-dossier-to-comey-duty-demanded-i-do-it | access-date=May 12, 2018}}</ref> Comey later confirmed that counterintelligence investigations were under way into possible links between Trump associates and Moscow.<ref name="Borger_4/28/2017"/>
After delivering his 16 memos, Steele received more information and composed the two-page "December memo", dated December 13. It mostly contained allegations against Trump's personal attorney, [[Michael Cohen (lawyer)|Michael Cohen]], which he denied.<ref name="Harding_5/10/2017"/><ref name="Cormier_5/5/2017"/> In an April 2017 court filing, Steele revealed previously unreported information that he had given a copy of his last memo to a "senior UK government national security official acting in his official capacity, on a confidential basis in hard copy form", because it "had implications for the national security of the US and the UK".<ref name="Borger_4/28/2017"/> Steele also "sent an encrypted version to Fusion with instructions to deliver a hard copy to Senator McCain."<ref name="Borger_4/28/2017"/>
=== Publication by BuzzFeed ===
In early January 2017, President-elect Trump<ref name="Kosoff_7/20/2017">{{cite web | last=Kosoff | first=Maya | title=Trump Thinks Comey Was Trying to Blackmail Him | website=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]] | date=July 20, 2017 | url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2017/07/trump-thinks-comey-was-trying-to-blackmail-him | access-date=April 7, 2018}}</ref> and President [[Barack Obama]] were separately briefed about the Russian interference in the election and on the existence of the dossier by the chiefs of several U.S. intelligence agencies. Vice President [[Joe Biden]] has confirmed that he and the president received briefings on the dossier and the allegations within.<ref name="Hensch_1/12/2017"/><ref name="Nowicki_1/13/2017">{{cite web | last=Nowicki | first=Dan | title=John McCain intrigue grows in Donald Trump dossier affair | website=[[The Arizona Republic]] | date=January 13, 2017 | url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/politics/arizona/2017/01/12/john-mccain-intrigue-grows-donald-trump-dossier-affair/96498178/ | access-date=February 11, 2018}}</ref><ref name="AOL_1/12/2017">{{cite web | last=AOL | first= | title=Biden: Obama and I were told about Trump dossier ahead of leaks | website=[[AOL]] | date=January 12, 2017 | url=https://www.aol.com/article/news/2017/01/12/biden-obama-and-i-were-told-about-trump-dossier-ahead-of-leaks/21654013/ | access-date=April 4, 2018}}</ref>
After the meeting with Obama, Trump was informed of the Russian election interference by Comey and Clapper on January 6, 2017, at a meeting in Trump Tower. After this meeting, Comey stayed behind and spoke privately with Trump, informing him of the dossier and some of its allegations.<ref name="Chan_4/16/2018">{{cite web | last=Chan | first=Tara Francis | title='Be very careful:' Comey was the first person to tell Trump about the Steele dossier before the inauguration - he couldn't have been more nervous | website=[[Business Insider]] | date=April 16, 2018 | url=https://www.businessinsider.com/when-was-trump-told-about-the-steele-dossier-2018-4 | access-date=April 19, 2018}}</ref> Trump later expressed that he felt that James Comey was trying to blackmail him at the meeting in Trump Tower, held two weeks before the inauguration.<ref name="Kosoff_7/20/2017"/> In April 2018, Comey said he did not inform Trump that the dossier was partly funded by Democrats because that "wasn't necessary for my goal, which was to alert him that we had this information."<ref name="Stracqualursi_4/13/2018"/><ref name="McCarthy_4/13/2018"/>
On January 10, 2017, CNN reported that classified documents presented to Obama and Trump the previous week included allegations that Russian operatives possess "compromising personal and financial information" about Trump. CNN stated that it would not publish specific details on the memos because it had not "independently corroborated the specific allegations."<ref name="Perez_Sciutto_Tapper_Bernstein_1/10/2017">{{cite web |first=Evan |last=Perez |first2=Jim |last2=Sciutto |authorlink2=Jim Sciutto |first3=Jake |last3=Tapper |authorlink3=Jake Tapper |first4=Carl |last4=Bernstein |authorlink4=Carl Bernstein |title=Intel chiefs presented Trump with claims of Russian efforts to compromise him |date=January 10, 2017 |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2017/01/10/politics/donald-trump-intelligence-report-russia/index.html |website=[[CNN]] |accessdate=January 11, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Wemple_1/11/2017">{{cite web |first=Erik |last=Wemple | title=BuzzFeed's ridiculous rationale for publishing the Trump-Russia dossier | website=[[The Washington Post]] | date=January 11, 2017 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/erik-wemple/wp/2017/01/10/buzzfeeds-ridiculous-rationale-for-publishing-the-trump-russia-dossier/ | access-date=April 4, 2018}}</ref> Following the CNN report,<ref name="Sutton_1/11/2017"/> [[BuzzFeed]] published a 35-page dossier that it said was the basis of the briefing, including unverified claims that Russian operatives had collected "embarrassing material" involving Trump that could be used to blackmail him.<ref name="Stein_1/10/2017"/><ref name="Mak_Suebsaeng_Weiss_ 1/10/2017">{{cite web |title=U.S. Spies Warn Trump and GOP: Russia Could Get You Next |url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2017/01/10/u-s-spies-warn-trump-and-gop-russia-could-get-you-next.html |website=[[The Daily Beast]] |date=January 10, 2017 |first=Tim |last=Mak |first2=Asawin |last2=Suebsaeng |first3=Michael |last3=Weiss |accessdate=January 11, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Shane_Goldman_Rosenberg_1/10/2017">{{cite news |title=Trump Received Unsubstantiated Report That Russia Had Damaging Information About Him |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/10/us/politics/donald-trump-russia-intelligence.html | date=January 10, 2017 |first=Scott |last=Shane |first2=Adam |last2=Goldman |first3=Matthew |last3=Rosenberg |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=January 11, 2017}}</ref>
BuzzFeed was harshly criticized for publishing what ''Washington Post'' columnist [[Margaret Sullivan (journalist)|Margaret Sullivan]] called "scurrilous allegations dressed up as an intelligence report meant to damage Donald Trump,"<ref name="Sullivan_1/11/2017">{{cite web | last=Sullivan | first=Margaret | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/how-buzzfeed-crossed-the-line-in-publishing-salacious-dossier-on-trump/2017/01/11/957b59f6-d801-11e6-9a36-1d296534b31e_story.html | title=How BuzzFeed crossed the line in publishing salacious 'dossier' on Trump | newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] | date=January 11, 2017 | accessdate=July 31, 2017 }}</ref> while ''The New York Times'' noted that the publication sparked a debate centering on the use of unsubstantiated information from anonymous sources.<ref name="Smith_1/23/2017">{{cite news | first=Ben | last=Smith | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/23/opinion/why-buzzfeed-news-published-the-dossier.html | title=Why BuzzFeed News Published the Dossier | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=January 23, 2017 | accessdate=February 11, 2017 }}</ref> BuzzFeed's executive staff said the materials were newsworthy because they were "in wide circulation at the highest levels of American government and media" and argued that this justified public release.<ref name="Graham_1/11/2017">{{cite journal |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/01/why-did-buzzfeed-publish-the-trump-dossier/512771/ |title=The Trouble With Publishing the Trump Dossier |first=David A. |last=Graham |journal=[[The Atlantic]] |date=January 11, 2017 |accessdate=January 10, 2018}}</ref>
In relation to a defamation lawsuit filed by [[Aleksej Gubarev]] against BuzzFeed, regarding their publication of the dossier, [[Master (judiciary)|Senior Master]] Barbara Fontaine stated that Steele was "in many respects in the same position as a whistle-blower" because of his actions "in sending part of the dossier to Senator John McCain and a senior government national security official, and in briefing sections of the US media." She said that "it was not known who provided the dossier to BuzzFeed but Mr Steele's evidence was that he was 'horrified and remains horrified' that it was published at all, let alone without substantial redactions."<ref name="Express_3/21/2018">{{cite web | last= | first= | title=Former British spy to provide evidence for BuzzFeed libel trial in US | website=[[Media of Jersey|Bailiwick Express]] | date=March 21, 2018 | url=https://gsy.bailiwickexpress.com/gsy/uk/former-british-spy-provide-evidence-buzzfeed-libel-trial-us/ | access-date=June 2, 2018}}</ref> Both Simpson and Steele have denied providing the dossier to BuzzFeed.<ref name="Donn_6/29/2018"/>
=== Format ===
When BuzzFeed published the 35-page dossier in January 2017, the individual memos were one- to three-pages long and page numbers 1-35 had been handwritten at the bottom. All but one had a typed date at the bottom. Each of the first 16 reports was assigned a typed number in the heading between 80 and 135, but the numeric order didn't always match the chronological order. The 17th memo, known as the "December memo", was numbered 166.<ref name="Bump_10/25/2017">{{cite web | last=Bump | first=Philip | title=What the Trump dossier says - and what it doesn't | website=[[The Washington Post]] | date=October 25, 2017 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/politics/wp/2017/10/25/what-the-trump-dossier-says-and-what-it-doesnt/ | access-date=May 9, 2018}}</ref> Of the original reports numbered 1-166, only certain reports were used for the dossier, and it is unknown what happened with the content of the other reports: "For example, the first report is labeled as '080,' with no indication given as to where the original 79 antecedents might have gone. The second report is then labeled '086,' creating yet another mystery as to 81 through 85, and what content they might contain that would otherwise bolster or contextualize what came before or what follows."<ref name="Weiss_Fitzpatrick_7/25/2018">{{cite web | last=Weiss | first=Michael | last2=Fitzpatrick | first2=Catherine A. | title=Dissecting the Trump-Russia Dossier | website=[[Coda Media|Coda Story]] | date=July 25, 2018 | url=https://codastory.com/disinformation-crisis/information-war/dissecting-the-trump-russia-dossier | access-date=August 21, 2018}}</ref>
Each memo started with a page heading in the same style as the first one shown here:
{{quote box | border = 2px | align = left | bgcolor = white | title = | halign = left | fontsize = 12 | quote = <center>CONFIDENTIAL/SENSITIVE SOURCE</center><p><p><p> COMPANY INTELLIGENCE REPORT 2016/080<p><p><p> US PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION: REPUBLICAN CANDIDATE DONALD TRUMP'S<br> ACTIVITIES IN RUSSIA AND COMPROMISING RELATIONSHIP WITH THE<br> KREMLIN<ref name="Harding_11/15/2017"/> {{hidden end}} |salign = left }} {{clear}}
== Authorship ==
{{main|Christopher Steele}} When [[CNN]] reported the existence of the dossier on January 10, 2017,<ref name="Perez_Sciutto_Tapper_Bernstein_1/10/2017"/><ref name="Nichols_Dilanian_1/11/2017">{{cite web |last=Nichols |first=Hans | last2=Dilanian | first2=Ken |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/former-british-spy-christopher-steele-prepared-explosive-trump-memo-n705891 |title=Former British Spy Christopher Steele Prepared Explosive Trump Memo |website=[[NBC News]] |date=January 11, 2017 |accessdate=January 12, 2017}}</ref> it did not name the author of the dossier, but revealed that he was British. Steele concluded that his anonymity had been "fatally compromised", and, realizing it was "only a matter of time until his name became public knowledge", fled into hiding with his family, in fear of "a prompt and potentially dangerous backlash against him from Moscow".<ref name="Staff_1/12/2017">{{cite web | author=Guardian Staff | url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jan/12/christopher-steele-ex-mi6-officer-named-as-author-of-trump-dossier |title=Christopher Steele, ex-MI6 officer, named as author of Trump dossier |date=January 12, 2017 | newspaper=[[The Guardian]] | access-date=January 18, 2017 }}</ref><ref name="Wood_1/12/2017">{{cite web |last=Wood |first=Paul |title=Trump memos ex-MI6 man 'in hiding' |website=[[BBC News]] |date=January 12, 2017 |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-38591382 |access-date=February 11, 2018}}</ref> ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' revealed Steele's name the next day, on January 11.<ref name="Hope_Rothfeld_Cullison_1/11/2017">{{cite web |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/christopher-steele-ex-british-intelligence-officer-said-to-have-prepared-dossier-on-trump-1484162553 |title=Christopher Steele, Ex-British Intelligence Officer, Said to Have Prepared Dossier on Trump |date=January 11, 2017 |first=Bradley |last=Hope |first2=Michael |last2=Rothfeld |first3=Alan |last3=Cullison |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |accessdate=January 18, 2017}}</ref> Orbis Business Intelligence Ltd, for whom Steele worked at the time the dossier was authored, and its director Christopher Burrows, a counterterrorism specialist,<ref name="Isikoff_Corn_3/17/2018"/> would not confirm or deny that Orbis had produced the dossier.<ref name="Nichols_Dilanian_1/11/2017"/><ref name="Shane_Confessore_Rosenberg_1/12/2017"/> On March 7, 2017, as some members of the [[U.S. Congress]] were expressing interest in meeting with or hearing testimony from Steele, he reemerged after weeks in hiding, appearing publicly on camera and stating, "I'm really pleased to be back here working again at the Orbis's offices in London today."<ref name="Withnall_3/7/2017">{{cite web |last=Withnall |first=Adam |title=Ex-British spy Christopher Steele breaks silence over Trump Russia dossier |website=[[The Independent]] |date=March 7, 2017 |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/donald-trump-russia-dossier-christopher-steele-ex-spy-british-a7616326.html |accessdate=March 26, 2017}}</ref>
Called by the media a "highly regarded Kremlin expert" and "one of MI6's greatest Russia specialists", Steele formerly worked for the British intelligence agency [[MI6]], heading its Russia Desk for three years at the end of his MI6 career. He entered MI6 in 1987, directly after his graduation from [[Cambridge University]].<ref name="Hughes_Robson_1/12/2017">{{cite web |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/picture-ex-mi6-officer-chris-9607903 |title=First picture of British spy behind Donald Trump 'dirty dossier' revealed |website=[[Daily Mirror]] |last1=Hughes |first1=Chris | last2=Robson | first2=Steve | date=January 12, 2017 | accessdate=February 11, 2018 }}</ref> He currently works for Orbis Business Intelligence Ltd, a private intelligence company he co-founded in London.<ref name="Neubert_Dilanian_Vinograd_Connor_1/13/2017">{{cite web | url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/christopher-steele-trump-dossier-author-real-life-james-bond-n706376 | title=The ex-spy who wrote the Trump dossier is nicknamed James Bond | first=Michele | last=Neubert | first2=Ken | last2=Dilanian | first3=Cassandra | last3=Vinograd | first4=Tracy | last4=Connor | date=January 13, 2017 | website=[[NBC News]] | accessdate=February 11, 2018 }}</ref><ref name="Behar_1/11/2017">{{cite web | last=Behar | first=Richard | title=Could This Be The British Ex-MI6 Agent Behind The Trump FBI Memos? | website=[[Forbes]] | date=January 11, 2017 | url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/richardbehar/2017/01/11/could-this-be-the-british-mi6-agent-behind-the-trump-fbi-memos/ | access-date=February 11, 2018}}</ref>
Wood, the former British ambassador to Moscow, has vouched for Steele's reputation.<ref name="Sengupta_1/13/2017"/> He views Steele as a "very competent professional operator ... I take the report seriously. I don't think it's totally implausible." He also stated that "the report's key allegation—that Trump and Russia's leadership were communicating via secret back channels during the presidential campaign—was eminently plausible".<ref name="Harding_Hopkins_1/13/2017">{{cite web |last=Harding |first=Luke |author-link=Luke Harding |last2=Hopkins |first2=Nick |date=January 13, 2017 |title=UK's former Moscow ambassador in spotlight over Trump dossier |work=[[The Guardian]] |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jan/13/uk-british-former-moscow-ambassador-andrew-wood-trump-dossier |accessdate=January 18, 2017}}</ref> FBI investigators reportedly treat Steele "as a peer", whose experience as a trusted Russia expert has included assisting the Justice Department, British prime ministers, and at least one U.S. president.<ref name="Hamburger_Helderman_2/6/2018">{{cite web | last1=Hamburger | first1=Tom | last2=Helderman | first2=Rosalind S. | title=Hero or hired gun? How a British former spy became a flash point in the Russia investigation. | website=[[The Washington Post]] | date=February 6, 2018 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/hero-or-hired-gun-how-a-british-former-spy-became-a-flash-point-in-the-russia-investigation/2018/02/06/94ea5158-0795-11e8-8777-2a059f168dd2_story.html | access-date=March 10, 2018}}</ref>
== Allegations ==
[[File:Vladimir Putin & Donald Trump in Helsinki, 16 July 2018 (2).jpg| thumb|upright=1.15|right| President [[Donald Trump]] meets with Russian President [[Vladimir Putin]] at [[Helsinki]], [[Finland]], on July 16, 2018.]] [[File:Michael Cohen headshot.jpg|upright|thumb|right|[[Michael Cohen (lawyer)|Michael Cohen]] (2011)]] [[File:Carter Page MSNBC June 2017 YouTube.png|thumb|upright|right|[[Carter Page]] (2017)]] The dossier contains multiple allegations, some of which have been publicly verified,<ref name="Sciutto_Perez_2/10/2017"/> others unverified,<ref name="Lee_12/26/2017"/> but, according to [[James Clapper]] and [[Shepard Smith]], none have been disproven,<ref name="MSNBC_5/22/2018">{{cite web | title=Manafort accuses Mueller deputy of leaking to press. TRANSCRIPT: 05/22/2018. The Rachel Maddow Show | website=[[MSNBC]] | date=May 22, 2018 | url=http://www.msnbc.com/transcripts/rachel-maddow-show/2018-05-22 | access-date=September 26, 2018}}</ref> with Smith stating: "None of the dossier, to Fox News's knowledge, has been disproven."<ref name="Hutzler_8//16/2018">{{cite web|url=https://www.newsweek.com/fox-news-host-contradicts-sean-hannity-trump-over-dossier-claims-1076388|title=Fox News Host Contradicts Sean Hannity, Trump Over Dossier Claims|last=Hutzler|first=Alexandra|date=August 16, 2018|website=[[Newsweek]]|accessdate=August 18, 2018|quote=[[Shep Smith]], an anchor at ''[[Fox News]]'', reported on August 15, 2018, that "Some of the assertions in the dossier have been confirmed. Other parts are unconfirmed. None of the dossier, to Fox News's knowledge, has been disproven."}}</ref> In some cases, public verification is hindered because information is classified.<ref name="Berke_6/8/2017"/><ref name="Truscott_8/18/2018"/>
According to [[Adam Schiff]], a major portion of the dossier's content is about Russian efforts to help Trump, and those allegations "turned out to be true".<ref name="Tau_11/15/2017"/>
Trump and Putin have repeatedly denied the allegations, and Trump has labeled the dossier "discredited", "debunked", "fictitious", and "fake news".<ref name="Breuninger_1/13/2018">{{cite web | last=Breuninger | first=Kevin | title=Fusion GPS testimony on infamous dossier shines new light on Trump's perilous financial ties | website=[[CNBC]] | date=January 13, 2018 | url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/01/13/trump-dossier-testimony-financial-ties.html | access-date=January 18, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Stefansky_11/11/2017">{{cite web | last=Stefansky | first=Emma | title=Trump: I Believe Putin "Means It" When He Denies Election Meddling | website=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]] | date=November 11, 2017 | url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2017/11/trump-believes-putin | access-date=January 25, 2018}}</ref> David A. Graham has noted that in spite of Trump's "mantra that 'there was no collusion'... it is clear that the Trump campaign and later transition were eager to work with Russia, and to keep that secret."<ref name="Graham_1/10/2018">{{cite web | last=Graham | first=David A. | title=What 'Fire and Fury' Shares With the Steele Dossier | website=[[The Atlantic]] | date=January 10, 2018 | url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2018/01/trump-dossier-michael-wolff-simpson-testimony/550175/ | access-date=February 2, 2018}}</ref>
=== Cultivation, conspiracy, and cooperation ===
* That "Russian authorities" had cultivated Trump "for at least 5 years", and that the operation was "supported and directed" by Putin.<ref name="Harding_11/15/2017">{{cite web | last=Harding | first=Luke | title=How Trump walked into Putin's web | website=[[The Guardian]] | date=November 15, 2017 | url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2017/nov/15/how-trump-walked-into-putins-web-luke | access-date=December 24, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Price_12/21/2017">{{cite web | last=Price | first=Greg | date=December 21, 2017 | title=What's True in the Trump 'Golden Shower' Dossier? Salacious Report Dogged President Throughout 2017 | website=[[Newsweek]] | url=https://www.newsweek.com/trump-golden-shower-dossier-russia-755831 | access-date=December 24, 2017 }}</ref> (Dossier, p. 1) * That Putin aimed to spread "discord and disunity" within the United States and between Western allies, whom he saw as a threat to Russia's interests.<ref name="Levine_1/12/2018"/><ref name="LeTourneau_1/13/2017"/> (Dossier, pp. 1–2) * That Trump was a "divisive" and "anti-Establishment" candidate, as well as "a pragmatist with whom they could do business". That Trump would remain a divisive force even if not elected.<ref name="Withnall_Sengupta_1/12/2017"/><ref name="Weindling_1/11/2017"/> (Dossier, p. 29) * That a major goal of the Russians in supporting Trump was "to upset the liberal international status quo, including on Ukraine-related sanctions, which was seriously disadvantaging the country.<ref name="Withnall_Sengupta_1/12/2017"/><ref name="Weindling_1/11/2017"/> (Dossier, pp. 28–29) * That the Russian government's support for Trump was originally conducted by the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Russia)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]], then by the [[Federal Security Service]] (FSB), and was eventually directly handled by the Russian presidency because of its "growing significance over time."<ref name="Withnall_Sengupta_1/12/2017"/><ref name="Sumter_11/16/2017">{{cite web | last=Sumter | first=Kyler | title=The five most interesting claims in the Donald Trump dossier | website=[[The Week]] | date=November 16, 2017 | url=https://www.theweek.co.uk/89760/the-five-most-interesting-claims-in-the-donald-trump-dossier | access-date=December 24, 2017}}</ref> (Dossier, p. 29) * That Trump had "so far declined various sweetener real estate business deals", but had "accepted a regular flow of intelligence from the Kremlin," notably on his political rivals.<ref name="Borger_1/11/2017">{{cite web |last=Borger | first=Julian | title=John McCain passes dossier alleging secret Trump-Russia contacts to FBI | website=[[The Guardian]] | date=January 11, 2017 | url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jan/10/fbi-chief-given-dossier-by-john-mccain-alleging-secret-trump-russia-contacts | access-date=February 26, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Drum_1/11/2017">{{cite web | last=Drum | first=Kevin | date=January 11, 2017 | title=US Intelligence: Evidence of Trump-Russia Ties Might Be Credible | website=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]] | url=https://www.motherjones.com/kevin-drum/2017/01/us-intelligence-evidence-trump-russia-ties-might-be-credible/ | accessdate=February 25, 2017 }}</ref> (Dossier, p. 1) * That there was "a well-developed conspiracy of co-operation between [the Trump campaign] and the Russian leadership," with information willingly exchanged in both directions. That this co-operation was "sanctioned at highest levels and involving Russian diplomatic staff based in the US." That the Trump campaign used "moles within DNC and hackers in the US as well as outside in Russia."<ref name="Harding_1/11/2017">{{cite web | last=Harding | first=Luke | title=What we know – and what's true – about the Trump-Russia dossier | website=[[The Guardian]] | date=January 11, 2017 | url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jan/11/trump-russia-dossier-explainer-details | access-date=December 24, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Beauchamp_3/22/2017">{{cite web | last=Beauchamp | first=Zack | title=What we know about evidence of coordination between Russia and the Trump campaign | website=[[Vox (website)|Vox]] | date=March 22, 2017 | url=https://www.vox.com/world/2017/3/22/15031052/trump-russia-campaign-coordination-cnn | access-date=March 9, 2018}}</ref> (Dossier, p. 7) * That Trump associates had established "an intelligence exchange [with the Kremlin] for at least 8 years." That Trump and his team had delivered "intelligence on the activities, business and otherwise, in the US of leading Russian oligarchs and their families", as requested by Putin.<ref name="Withnall_Sengupta_1/12/2017"/><ref name="Wood_3/30/2017">{{cite web |last=Wood |first=Paul |title=Trump Russia dossier key claim 'verified' |website=[[BBC News]] |date=March 30, 2017 |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-39435786 |access-date=December 24, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Weindling_1/11/2017"/> (Dossier, p. 11) * That the Trump camp became angry and resentful toward Putin when they realized he was not only aiming to weaken Clinton and bolster Trump, but was attempting to "undermine the US government and democratic system more generally."<ref name="Weindling_1/11/2017"/> (Dossier, p. 17)

=== Possible earlier interest in Trump ===
Although the dossier alleged in June 2016 that the Kremlin had been cultivating Trump for "at least five years", [[Luke Harding]] wrote that the Soviet Union had been interested in him since 1987. In his book ''Collusion'', Harding asserts that the "top level of the Soviet diplomatic service arranged his 1987 Moscow visit. With assistance from the KGB." Then-KGB head [[Vladimir Kryuchkov]] "wanted KGB staff abroad to recruit more Americans." Harding proceeds to describe the KGB's cultivation process, and posits that they may have opened a file on Trump as early as 1977, when he married Czech model [[Ivana Zelníčková]]; the Soviet spies may have closely observed and analyzed the couple from that time on.<ref name="Harding_11/19/2017">{{cite web |last=Harding |first=Luke |title=The Hidden History of Trump's First Trip to Moscow |website=[[Politico]] |date=November 19, 2017 |url=https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2017/11/19/trump-first-moscow-trip-215842 |access-date=January 21, 2018}}</ref><ref name="NPR_Harding_11/21/2017">{{cite web | title=Journalist Investigating Trump And Russia Says 'Full Picture Is One Of Collusion' | website=[[NPR]] | date=November 21, 2017 | url=https://www.npr.org/2017/11/21/565654507/journalist-investigating-trump-and-russia-says-full-picture-is-one-of-collusion | access-date=May 3, 2018}}</ref>
== Denials of specific accusations == === Michael Cohen ===
[[File:Full Lanny Davis Interview- Michael Cohen Was 'Never, Ever' In Prague - MTP Daily - MSNBC.webm|thumb|Referring to the Steele dossier, Cohen's attorney [[Lanny Davis]] stated that Cohen was "never, ever" in Prague. (starting at 9:00 in the video interview)]] The dossier alleges that Trump's personal attorney, Michael Cohen, met with Russian officials in Prague in 2016 with the objective of paying those who had [[Democratic National Committee cyber attacks|hacked the DNC]] and to "cover up all traces of the hacking operation".
