Cohen has denied the allegations against him,<ref name="Borger_4/28/2017" /><ref name="Harding_5/10/2017"/><ref name="Cormier_5/5/2017">{{cite web | last=Cormier | first=Anthony | title=This Is The Inside Of Trump's Lawyer's Passport | website=[[BuzzFeed]] | date=May 5, 2017 | url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/anthonycormier/trumps-lawyer-showed-you-the-cover-of-his-passport-heres | access-date=December 24, 2017}}</ref> stating that he was in Los Angeles between August 23 and 29, and in New York for the entire month of September<ref name="Gray_1/10/2017">{{cite web | last=Gray | first=Rosie | title=Michael Cohen: 'It Is Fake News Meant to Malign Mr. Trump' | website=[[The Atlantic]] | date=January 10, 2017 | url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/01/michael-cohen-it-is-fake-news-meant-to-malign-mr-trump/512762/ | access-date=December 24, 2017 | quote= I'm telling you emphatically that I've not been to Prague, I've never been to Czech [Republic], I've not been to Russia. }}</ref> and that "I have never been to Prague in my life".<ref name="Bump_4/14/2018">{{cite web | last=Bump | first=Philip | title=Michael Cohen's visiting Prague would be a huge development in the Russia investigation | website=[[The Washington Post]] | date=April 14, 2018 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/politics/wp/2018/04/14/michael-cohen-visiting-prague-would-be-a-huge-development-in-the-russia-investigation/ | access-date=July 4, 2018}}</ref>
According to a Czech intelligence source, as of January 11, 2017, there was no record of him entering Prague by plane, but ''[[Respekt]]'' magazine and ''Politico'' pointed out that he could have entered by car or train from a neighboring country within the [[Schengen Area]], for example Italy. In the latter case, a record of Cohen entering the Schengen zone from a non-Schengen country should exist.<ref name="RFE/RL_1/11/2017">{{cite web | author=RFE/RL | title=Report: Czech Intelligence Says No Evidence Trump Lawyer Traveled To Prague | website=[[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] | date=January 11, 2017 | url=https://www.rferl.org/a/czech-intelligence-trump-lawyer-prague-meeting/28226228.html | access-date=January 19, 2018 | quote= According to [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]], 'A Czech intelligence source told the ''[[Respekt]]'' magazine that there is no record of Cohen arriving in Prague by plane, although the news weekly pointed out he could have traveled by car or train from a nearby EU country, avoiding passport control under [[Schengen zone]] travel rules.' }}</ref><ref name="Meyer_12/6/2017">{{cite web | last=Meyer | first=Josh | title=Investigators probe European travel of Trump associates | website=[[Politico]] | date=December 6, 2017 | url=https://politi.co/2jkaxqp | access-date=February 27, 2018}}</ref>
In April 2018, ''[[The McClatchy Company|McClatchy]]'' reported that the Special Counsel had evidence that Michael Cohen had secretly visited Prague in the late summer of 2016, as reported by Steele, and that Mueller's investigators had "traced evidence that Cohen entered the Czech Republic through Germany",<ref name="Stone_Gordon_4/13/2018">{{cite web | url=https://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/politics-government/white-house/article208870264.html | title=Sources: Mueller has evidence Cohen was in Prague in 2016, confirming part of dossier | work=[[The McClatchy Company|McClatchy DC Bureau]] | date=April 13, 2018 | accessdate=April 16, 2018 | last=Stone | first=Peter | last2=Gordon | first2=Greg}}</ref> a claim which ''[[The Spectator]]'' reported was "backed up by one intelligence source in London".<ref name="Cockburn_7/3/2018">{{cite web | last=Cockburn | title=What does Michael Cohen know? | website=[[The Spectator]] | date=July 3, 2018 | url=https://usa.spectator.co.uk/2018/07/what-does-michael-cohen-know/ | access-date=July 4, 2018}}</ref> In August 2018, BBC correspondent [[Paul Wood (journalist)|Paul Wood]] wrote: "I have spoken to one intelligence source who says Mueller is examining 'electronic records' that would place Cohen in Prague."<ref name="Wood_8/25/2018">{{cite web | last=Wood | first=Paul | title=Trumpworld is spinning out of control | website=[[The Spectator]] | date=August 25, 2018 | url=https://www.spectator.co.uk/2018/08/trumpworld-is-spinning-out-of-control/ | access-date=September 29, 2018}}</ref>
Cohen has maintained that he has never in his life traveled to Prague, but ''Mother Jones'' reported that he privately admitted "I was in Prague for one afternoon 14 years ago."<ref name="Corn_4/20/2018"/> During an interview with [[Chuck Todd]] on August 22, 2018, Cohen's attorney [[Lanny Davis]] stated that Cohen was "never, ever" in Prague, and that all allegations mentioning his name in the Steele dossier are false.<ref name="MSNBC_Davis_8/22/2018">{{cite interview |url=https://www.msnbc.com/mtp-daily/watch/full-lanny-davis-interview-cohen-was-never-ever-in-prague-1304432195563?v=raila |title=Full Lanny Davis Interview: Cohen was 'never, ever' in Prague |subject=[[Lanny Davis]] |interviewer=[[Chuck Todd]] |publisher=[[MSNBC]] |minutes=9 |date=August 22, 2018 |access-date=August 25, 2018}}</ref>
According to ''McClatchy'': "If Cohen met with Russians and hackers in Prague as described in the dossier, it would provide perhaps the most compelling evidence to date that the Russians and Trump campaign aides were collaborating."<ref name="Stone_Gordon_4/13/2018"/>
=== Aleksej Gubarev ===
Gubarev has denied all accusations made in the dossier and has sued Buzzfeed and Fusion GPS.<ref name="Goldstein_Hall_Gordon_2/3/2017"/><ref name="Hall_9/21/2018"/>
=== Paul Manafort ===
Manafort has "denied taking part in any collusion with the Russian state, but [[Foreign Agents Registration Act|registered himself as a foreign agent]] retroactively after it was revealed his firm received more than $17m working as a lobbyist for a pro-Russian Ukrainian party."<ref name="Borger_10/7/2017"/>
=== Carter Page ===
Page originally denied meeting any Russian officials, but his later testimony, acknowledging that he had met with senior Russian officials at Rosneft, has been interpreted as corroboration of portions of the dossier.<ref name="Raju_Herb_Polantz_11/8/2017"/><ref name="Lanktree_11/7/2017">{{cite news |date=November 7, 2017 |first=Graham |last=Lanktree |title=Carter Page Attacked Christopher Steele's Trump Dossier But His Testimony Raised Questions Over Russian Meetings |website=[[Newsweek]] |url=https://www.newsweek.com/carter-page-testimony-attacks-christopher-steeles-trump-dossier-703691 | access-date=April 2, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Kelly_11/6/2017">{{cite news |date=November 6, 2017 |first=Erin |last=Kelly |title=Trump campaign adviser Carter Page acknowledges meeting with senior Russian officials: transcript |website=[[USA Today]] |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2017/11/06/trump-campaign-adviser-carter-page-acknowledges-meeting-senior-russian-officials-transcript/838647001/ | access-date=April 2, 2018}}</ref>
=== Donald Trump ===
Trump has denied the "[[golden showers]]" allegation by claiming he is a "[[germaphobe]]".<ref name="Francis_Groll_6/7/2017">{{cite news | last1=Francis | first1=David | last2=Groll | first2=Elias | title=Comey: Trump Denied He Was Involved With 'Hookers' in Russia | work=[[Foreign Policy]] | date=June 7, 2017 | url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2017/06/07/comey-trump-denied-he-was-involved-with-hookers-in-russia/ | access-date=January 25, 2018}}</ref> James Comey has written that Trump, on two different occasions, attempted to prove it couldn't have happened by claiming he did not stay overnight in Moscow. Those [[alibi]]s have been disproven.<ref name="Chait_4/13/2018">{{cite news | last=Chait | first=Jonathan | title=I'm a Peeliever and You Should Be, Too. 5 Reasons the Pee Tape Is Probably Real. | work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] | date=April 13, 2018 | url=https://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2018/04/im-a-peeliever-and-you-should-be-too.html | access-date=April 16, 2018}}</ref> On April 13, 2018, James Comey said he did not know whether Trump "was with prostitutes peeing on each other in Moscow in 2013", adding "It's possible, but I don't know".<ref name="Stracqualursi_4/13/2018">{{cite news | last=Stracqualursi | first=Veronica | title=Comey: 'I don't know' if Trump was with prostitutes in Moscow | work=[[CNN]] | date=April 13, 2018 | url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/04/13/politics/james-comey-trump-dossier/index.html | access-date=April 15, 2018}}</ref><ref name="McCarthy_4/13/2018">{{cite news | last=McCarthy | first=Tom | title='Slime ball': Trump attacks Comey after new book likens president to mafia boss | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=April 13, 2018 | url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/apr/13/trump-attacks-james-comey-fbi-director-book | access-date=April 15, 2018}}</ref>
On April 26, 2018,<ref name="Harrington_4/26/2018"/> three days after ''Bloomberg News'' revealed that flight records proved Trump spent one night in Moscow,<ref name="Silver_4/23/2018"/> Trump phoned in to ''Fox & Friends'' and, alluding to "one of the most salacious allegations in the so-called Steele dossier", stated that he did stay overnight in Russia. He also accused Comey of lying.<ref name="Harrington_4/26/2018">{{cite web | last=Harrington | first=Rebecca | title=In long rant on 'Fox & Friends,' Trump acknowledges staying overnight in Moscow — alluding to the most salacious allegation in the Steele dossier | website=[[Business Insider]] | date=April 26, 2018 | url=https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-stayed-overnight-in-moscow-russia-steele-dossier-2018-4 | access-date=October 6, 2018}}</ref> When Comey was asked by [[Anderson Cooper]] if he thought that it was "significant that the President lied to you twice?", Comey replied that "It's always significant when someone lies to you, especially about something you're not asking about. It tends to reflect a consciousness of guilt."<ref name="Malloy_4/26/2018">{{cite web | last=Malloy | first=Allie | title=Trump denies that he told Comey he didn't stay overnight in Moscow | website=[[CNN]] | date=April 26, 2018 | url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/04/26/politics/donald-trump-james-comey-moscow/index.html | access-date=October 14, 2018}}</ref>
In a June 21, 2018, debate, Comey, when asked if he believed "all the salacious" stories in the dossier, replied: "When I first saw it I didn't believe it at all... [now] I think it's possible that it's true." He said he changed his view after his encounters with President Trump.<ref name="Evening_Standard_6/22/2018">{{cite web | title=The Londoner: Comey swayed by Trump sex dossier | website=[[London Evening Standard]] | date=June 22, 2018 | url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/londoners-diary/comey-swayed-by-trump-sex-dossier-a3869581.html | access-date=June 23, 2018}}</ref> Comey has stated that, at the time he was fired, the allegations had not been verified.<ref name="Chiacu_Moore_4/14/018">{{cite news | last1=Chiacu | first1=Doina | last2=Moore| first2=Angela | title=Trump, called an unethical liar in book, blasts ex-FBI chief as 'slime ball' | work=[[Reuters]] | date=April 14, 2018 | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-comey/former-fbi-director-trump-wanted-fbi-to-disprove-salacious-dossier-idUSKBN1HK1OZ | access-date=April 15, 2018}}</ref>
Contradicting what Trump told Comey, [[Thomas Roberts (television journalist)|Thomas Roberts]], the host of the Miss Universe contest, has confirmed that "Trump was in Moscow for one full night and at least part of another." (November 8–10).<ref name="Kirell_4/24/2018">{{cite news | last=Kirell | first=Andrew | title=Miss Universe 2013 Host Thomas Roberts Confirms: Trump Stayed Overnight in Moscow | work=[[The Daily Beast]] | date=April 24, 2018 | url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/miss-universe-2013-host-thomas-roberts-confirms-trump-stayed-overnight-in-moscow | access-date=April 26, 2018}}</ref> According to flight records, [[Keith Schiller]]'s testimony, social media posts, and Trump's close friend, [[Aras Agalarov]], Trump arrived by private jet on Friday, November 8, going to the Ritz-Carlton hotel and booking into the presidential suite, where the "golden showers" incident is alleged to have occurred.<ref name="Mayer_3/12/2018"/><ref name="Silver_Pismennaya_7/13/2017">{{cite news | last=Silver | first=Vernon | last2=Pismennaya | first2=Evgenia | title=Trump's Two Nights of Parties in Moscow Echo Years Later | work=[[Bloomberg News]] | date=July 13, 2017 | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-07-13/trump-s-two-nights-of-parties-in-moscow-reverberate-years-later | access-date=March 3, 2018}}</ref>
There were a number of meetings and a lunch that day. Schiller related that a Russian approached them "around lunch-time"<ref name="Raju_Herb_11/10/2017"/> and offered to "send five women to Trump's hotel room that night".<ref name="Corn_Isikoff_3/8/2018"/> According to "multiple sources", the offer "came from a Russian who was accompanying Emin Agalarov".<ref name="Raju_Herb_11/10/2017"/> "Schiller said he didn't take the offer seriously and told the Russian, 'We don't do that type of stuff'."<ref name="Corn_Isikoff_3/8/2018"/> Schiller later testified that he rejected the offer, stating that "he took the offer as a joke".<ref name="Raju_Herb_11/10/2017"/> That evening Trump attended a birthday party for Aras Agalarov.<ref name="Smith_4/23/2018">{{cite web | last=Smith | first=Allan | title=Flight records obtained by Bloomberg shed new light on Trump's heavily scrutinized Moscow trip - and they seem to contradict what he told James Comey | website=[[Business Insider]] | date=April 23, 2018 | url=https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-moscow-flight-records-misled-james-comey-2018-4 | access-date=October 6, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Corn_Isikoff_3/8/2018">{{cite news | last1=Corn | first1=David | last2=Isikoff | first2=Michael | date=March 8, 2018 | title=What Happened in Moscow: The Inside Story of How Trump's Obsession With Putin Began | work=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]] | url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2018/03/russian-connection-what-happened-moscow-inside-story-trump-obsession-putin-david-corn-michael-isikoff/ | accessdate=April 15, 2018}}</ref>
They returned to the hotel after the party. Schiller testified that, "On their way up to Trump's hotel room that night, [he told Trump] about the offer and Trump laughed it off".<ref name="Raju_Herb_11/10/2017"/> He then accompanied Trump to his room, stayed outside the door for a few minutes, and then left,<ref name="Raju_Herb_11/10/2017">{{cite news |last1=Raju |first1=Manu |last2=Herb |first2=Jeremy |url=https://www.cnn.com/2017/11/09/politics/keith-schiller-russian-offer-women-2013-moscow/index.html |title=Ex-Trump security chief testifies he rejected 2013 Russian offer of women for Trump in Moscow |work=[[CNN]] |date=November 10, 2017 |accessdate=January 26, 2018}}</ref> and, according to one source, Schiller "could not say for sure what happened during the remainder of the night."<ref name="Dilanian_Allen_11/9/2017">{{cite news|last1=Dilanian |first1=Ken |last2=Allen |first2=Jonathan |date=November 9, 2017 |title=Trump Bodyguard Keith Schiller Testifies Russian Offered Trump Women, Was Turned Down |work=[[NBC News]] |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/trump-bodyguard-testifies-russian-offered-trump-women-was-turned-down-n819386 |accessdate=February 28, 2018}}</ref>
On Saturday, Facebook posts showed he was at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.<ref name="Smith_4/23/2018"/> That evening he attended the Miss Universe pageant, followed by an after party. He then returned to his hotel, packed, and flew back to the United States.<ref name="Silver_4/23/2018">{{cite news | last=Silver | first=Vernon | title=Flight Records Illuminate Mystery of Trump's Moscow Nights | work=[[Bloomberg News]] | date=April 23, 2018 | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-04-23/flight-records-illuminate-mystery-of-trump-s-moscow-nights | access-date=April 24, 2018}}</ref>
== Veracity ==
Steele and the dossier have become "the central point of contention in the political brawl raging around"<ref name="Hamburger_Helderman_2/6/2018"/> the [[Special Counsel investigation (2017–present)|Special counsel investigation]] into [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]]. Those who believe Steele consider him a hero who tried to warn about the Kremlin's meddling in the election, and people who distrust him consider him a "hired gun" used to attack Trump.<ref name="Hamburger_Helderman_2/6/2018"/> The dossier's "broad assertion that Russia waged a campaign to interfere in the election is now accepted as fact by the US intelligence community."<ref name="Perez_Prokupecz_Brown_10/25/2017"/> With the passage of time and further revelations from various investigations and sources, it is becoming clearer that the overall thrust of the dossier was accurate, but some details appear to be merely disinformation:<ref name="Donn_6/29/2018">{{cite web | last=Donn | first=Jeff | title=Some questions in Trump-Russia dossier now finding answers | date=June 29, 2018 | website=[[AP News]] | url=https://apnews.com/55b8a55d5a7545b99d0f915affb7d852 | access-date=June 29, 2018}}</ref>
{{quote|"Some of the dossier's broad threads have now been independently corroborated. U.S. intelligence agencies and the special counsel's investigation into Russian election interference did eventually find that Kremlin-linked operatives ran an elaborate operation to promote Trump and hurt Democratic opponent Hillary Clinton, as the dossier says in its main narrative." |author = Jeff Donn |title = "Some Questions in Trump-Russia Dossier Now Finding Answers" |source = ''[[Associated Press]]'' (June 29, 2018)<ref name="Donn_6/29/2018"/> }}
=== Reputation in the U.S. intelligence community ===
On January 11, 2017, [[Paul Wood (journalist)|Paul Wood]], of [[BBC News]], wrote that the salacious information in Steele's dossier was also reported by "multiple intelligence sources" and "at least one East European intelligence service". They reported that "compromising material on Mr. Trump" included "more than one tape, not just video, but audio as well, on more than one date, in more than one place, in both Moscow and St. Petersburg." While also mentioning that "nobody should believe something just because an intelligence agent says it",<ref name="Lange_1/11/2017">{{cite web |url=https://theweek.com/speedreads/672669/bbc-claims-second-source-backs-trump-dossier |title=BBC claims a second source backs up Trump dossier |date=January 11, 2017 |first=Jeva |last=Lange |work=[[The Week]] | access-date=April 1, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Hope_Rothfeld_Cullison_1/11/2017"/> Wood added that "the CIA believes it is credible that the Kremlin has such ''kompromat''—or compromising material—on the next US commander in chief" and "a joint taskforce, which includes the CIA and the FBI, has been investigating allegations that the Russians may have sent money to Mr Trump's organisation or his election campaign".<ref name="Wood_compromising_1/12/2017">{{cite web |last=Wood |first=Paul |title=Trump 'compromising' claims: How and why did we get here? |website=[[BBC News]] |date=January 12, 2017 |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-38589427 |access-date=February 19, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Drum_1/12/2017">{{cite web |last=Drum |first=Kevin |url=https://www.motherjones.com/kevin-drum/2017/01/bbcs-paul-wood-there-are-four-sources-possible-trump-russia-blackmail |title=BBC's Paul Wood: There are four sources for claims of possible Trump–Russia blackmail |work=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]] |date=January 12, 2017 | access-date=April 1, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Lange_1/11/2017"/>
On January 12, 2017, Susan Hennessey, a former [[National Security Agency]] lawyer now with the [[Brookings Institution]], stated: "My general take is that the intelligence community and law enforcement seem to be taking these claims seriously. That itself is highly significant. But it is not the same as these allegations being verified. Even if this was an intelligence community document—which it isn't—this kind of raw intelligence is still treated with skepticism."<ref name="Tracy_1/11/2017"/><ref name="Hennessey_Wittes_1/12/2017">{{cite news |first=Susan |last=Hennessey |first2=Benjamin |last2=Wittes |title=Why Are the Trump Allegations Hanging Around When They Haven't Been Substantiated? |date=January 12, 2017 |website=[[Lawfare (blog)|Lawfare]] |url=https://www.lawfareblog.com/why-are-trump-allegations-hanging-around-when-they-havent-been-substantiated | access-date=April 1, 2018 |quote="... the salacious allegations and the reports of collusion between the Trump campaign and Russian intelligence do not take place in a vacuum. They take place amidst the background of a great deal of public evidence of ties between the Trump campaign and Russian actors."}}</ref> Hennessey and [[Benjamin Wittes]] wrote that "the current state of the evidence makes a powerful argument for a serious public inquiry into this matter".<ref name="Hennessey_Wittes_1/12/2017"/>
On February 10, 2017, CNN reported that some communications between "senior Russian officials and other Russian individuals" described in the dossier had been corroborated by multiple U.S. officials. They "took place between the same individuals on the same days and from the same locations as detailed in the dossier". Some persons were known to be "heavily involved" in collecting information that could hurt Clinton and aid Trump. CNN was unable to confirm whether conversations were related to Trump. Sources told CNN that some conversations had been "intercepted during routine intelligence gathering", but refused to reveal the content of conversations, or specify which communications were intercepted because the information was classified. U.S. officials said the corroboration gave "US intelligence and law enforcement 'greater confidence' in the credibility of some aspects of the dossier as they continue to actively investigate its contents". They also reported that American intelligence agencies had examined Steele and his "vast network throughout Europe and found him and his sources to be credible."<ref name="Sciutto_Perez_2/10/2017"/>
On March 30, 2017, Paul Wood reported that the FBI was using the dossier as a roadmap for its investigation.<ref name="Bertrand_3/30/2017">{{cite web |last=Bertrand |first=Natasha |title=The FBI is reportedly using the explosive Trump–Russia dossier as a 'roadmap' for its investigation |website=[[Business Insider]] |date=March 30, 2017 |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-russia-dossier-fbi-investigation-2017-3 |accessdate=April 19, 2017}}</ref> On April 18, 2017, CNN reported that, according to U.S. officials, information from the dossier had been used as part of the basis for getting the [[FISA]] warrant to monitor Page in October 2016. Officials told CNN this information would have had to be independently corroborated by the FBI before being used to obtain the warrant.<ref name="Perez_Prokupecz_Raju_4/18/2017">{{cite web |last=Perez |first=Evan |last2=Prokupecz |first2=Shimon |last3=Raju |first3=Manu |title=FBI used dossier allegations to bolster Trump–Russia investigation |website=[[CNN]] |date=April 18, 2017 |url=https://www.cnn.com/2017/04/18/politics/fbi-dossier-carter-page-donald-trump-russia-investigation/index.html |accessdate=April 19, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Nakashima_Barrett_Entous_4/11/2017">{{cite web | first1=Ellen | last1=Nakashima | first2=Devlin | last2=Barrett | first3=Adam | last3=Entous | title=FBI obtained FISA warrant to monitor former Trump adviser Carter Page | website=[[The Washington Post]] | date=April 11, 2017 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/fbi-obtained-fisa-warrant-to-monitor-former-trump-adviser-carter-page/2017/04/11/620192ea-1e0e-11e7-ad74-3a742a6e93a7_story.html | access-date=April 24, 2018}}</ref> In his testimony before Congress, Glenn Simpson "confirmed that the FBI had sources of its own and that whatever the FBI learned from Steele was simply folded into its ongoing work."<ref name="Dreyfuss_1/12/2018">{{cite web | last=Dreyfuss | first=Bob | date=January 12, 2018 | title=Secrets of the Trump-Russia Dossier | website=[[The Nation]] | url=https://www.thenation.com/article/secrets-of-the-trump-russia-dossier/ | accessdate=August 16, 2018 }}</ref>
British journalist [[Julian Borger]] wrote on October 7, 2017, that "Steele's reports are being taken seriously after lengthy scrutiny by federal and congressional investigators", at least Steele's assessment that Russia had conducted a campaign to interfere in the 2016 election to Clinton's detriment; that part of the Steele dossier "has generally gained in credibility, rather than lost it".<ref name="Borger_10/7/2017"/>
On October 11, 2017, it was reported that Senator [[Sheldon Whitehouse]] ([[Democratic Party (United States)|D]]-[[Rhode Island]]), member of the [[Senate Judiciary Committee]] (SJC), had stated: "As I understand it, a good deal of his information remains unproven, but none of it has been disproven, and considerable amounts of it have been proven."<ref name="Hosenball_Landay_10/11/2017">{{cite web |last1=Hosenball |first1=Mark |last2=Landay |first2=Jonathan |title=U.S. congressional panels spar over 'Trump dossier' on Russia contacts |website=[[Reuters]] |date=October 11, 2017 |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-russia-dossier/u-s-congressional-panels-spar-over-trump-dossier-on-russia-contacts-idUSKBN1CG02L |accessdate=December 29, 2017}}</ref>
On October 27, 2017, [[Robert S. Litt]], a former lawyer for the [[Director of National Intelligence]], was quoted as stating that the dossier "played absolutely no role" in the intelligence community's determination that Russia had interfered in the 2016 U.S. presidential election.<ref name="Bertrand_10/27/2017">{{cite web |last=Bertrand |first=Natasha |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/robert-litt-says-dossier-played-no-role-in-intel-community-russia-assessment-2017-10 |title=Former intel official: Trump–Russia dossier 'played no role' in our analysis of Russian meddling |work=[[Business Insider]] |date=October 27, 2017 |accessdate=October 29, 2017}}</ref>
On November 15, 2017, [[Adam Schiff]] stated that much of the dossier's content is about Russian efforts to help Trump, and those allegations "turned out to be true", something later affirmed by the [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections#January 2017 Intelligence Community Assessment|January 6, 2017, intelligence community assessment]] released by the [[Office of the Director of National Intelligence|ODNI]].<ref name="Tau_11/15/2017">{{cite web | last=Tau | first=Byron | title=Rep. Schiff Rejects Efforts to Dismiss Dossier on Trump | website=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | date=November 15, 2017 | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/rep-schiff-rejects-efforts-to-dismiss-dossier-on-trump-1510777602 | access-date=July 22, 2018}}</ref>
On December 7, 2017, commentator [[Jonathan Chait]] wrote that as "time goes by, more and more of the claims first reported by Steele have been borne out", with the mainstream media "treat[ing] "[the dossier] as gossip" whereas the intelligence community "take it seriously".<ref name="Chait_12/7/2017">{{cite web |last=Chait |first=Jonathan |title=The Steele Dossier on Trump and Russia Is Looking More and More Real |website=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] |date=December 7, 2017 |url=https://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2017/12/the-steele-dossier-on-trump-is-looking-more-and-more-real.html |access-date=December 28, 2017 |quote="As time goes by, more and more of the claims first reported by Steele have been borne out. In general, there is a split between the credibility afforded the dossier by the mainstream media and by intelligence professionals. The former treat it as gossip; the latter take it seriously."}}</ref>
On January 29, 2018, Mark Warner, the top Democrat on the Senate Intelligence Committee, said "little of that dossier has either been fully proven or conversely, disproven".<ref name="Wheeler_2/1/2018">{{cite news | last1=Wheeler | first1=Marcy | title=Democrats Embraced a Flawed Dossier – And Gave Republicans an Opening | url=https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2018/02/01/russia-steele-dossier-democrats-republicans-216921 | work=[[Politico]] | date=February 1, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Glasser_1/29/2018">{{cite news | first=Susan B. | last=Glasser | title=Mark Warner: The Full Transcript | url=https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2018/01/29/mark-warner-the-full-transcript-216543 | work=[[Politico]] | date=January 29, 2018}}</ref>
John Sipher, who served 28 years as a clandestine CIA agent, including heading the agency's Russia program, said investigating the dossier allegations requires access to non-public records. He said "[p]eople who say it's all garbage, or all true, are being politically biased", adding he believes that while the dossier may not be correct in every detail, it is "generally credible" and "In the intelligence business, you don't pretend you're a hundred per cent accurate. If you're seventy or eighty per cent accurate, that makes you one of the best." He said the Mueller investigation would ultimately judge its merits.<ref name="Mayer_3/12/2018"/> Sipher has written that "Many of my former CIA colleagues have taken the [dossier] reports seriously since they were first published."<ref name="Sipher_9/11/2017"/>
During his April 15, 2018, ABC News interview with [[George Stephanopoulos]], former FBI Director [[James Comey]] described Steele as a "credible source": "It was coming from a credible source, someone with a track record, someone who was a credible and respected member of an allied intelligence service during his career, and so it was important that we try to understand it, and see what could we verify, what could we rule in or rule out."<ref name="Keneally_4/15/2018">{{cite web | last=Keneally | first=Meghan | title=Comey says he believes the source of the Steele 'dossier' to be 'credible' | website=[[ABC News]] | date=April 15, 2018 | url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/comey-believes-source-steele-dossier-credible/story?id=54488781 | access-date=April 17, 2018}}</ref>
In May 2018, former career intelligence officer [[James Clapper]] believed that "more and more" of the dossier had been validated over time.<ref name="O'Hehir_5/26/2018">{{cite web | last=O'Hehir | first=Andrew | date=May 26, 2018 | title=James Clapper on Donald Trump, Edward Snowden, torture and "the knowability of truth". Obama's intelligence chief on the Steele dossier (mostly true), the Trump danger and whether he lied to Congress | website=[[Salon (website)|Salon]] | url=https://www.salon.com/2018/05/26/james-clapper-on-donald-trump-edward-snowden-torture-and-the-knowability-of-truth/ | accessdate=September 1, 2018 }}</ref><ref name="Bowden_5/26/2018">{{cite web | last=Bowden | first=John | title=Clapper: 'More and more' of Steele dossier proving to be true | website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] | date=May 26, 2018 | url=https://thehill.com/policy/national-security/389522-clapper-more-and-more-of-steele-dossier-proving-to-be-true | access-date=May 27, 2018}}</ref>
=== Varied reactions about veracity ===
Steele, the author of the dossier, said he believes that 70–90% of the dossier is accurate,<ref name="Borger_11/15/2017"/><ref name="Isikoff_Corn_3/17/2018"/> In testimony to Congress, Simpson quoted "Steele as saying that any intelligence, especially from Russia, is bound to carry intentional disinformation, but that Steele believes his dossier is 'largely not disinformation'."<ref name="Donn_6/29/2018"/> except for the "golden showers" allegation, which he gives a 50% chance of being true.<ref name="Isikoff_Corn_3/17/2018"/>
Other observers and experts have had varying reactions to the dossier. Generally, "former intelligence officers and other national-security experts" urged "skepticism and caution" but still took "the fact that the nation's top intelligence officials chose to present a summary version of the dossier to both President Obama and President-elect Trump" as an indication "that they may have had a relatively high degree of confidence that at least some of the claims therein were credible, or at least worth investigating further".<ref name="Tracy_1/11/2017">{{cite news |first=Abigail |last=Tracy |url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2017/01/donald-trump-russia-report-intelligence-community |title=What Intelligence Experts Think of the Explosive Trump–Russia Report |website=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]] |date=January 11, 2017 |accessdate=July 31, 2017}}</ref>
Vice President [[Joe Biden]] told reporters that, while he and Obama were receiving a briefing on the extent of election hacking attempts, there was a two-page addendum which addressed the contents of the Steele dossier.<ref name="Hensch_1/12/2017">{{cite web |url=https://thehill.com/policy/national-security/intelligence/313999-biden-intel-officials-warned-us-of-trump-dossier |title=Biden: Intel officials warned us of Trump dossier |last=Hensch |first=Mark |date=January 12, 2017 |newspaper=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |access-date=February 1, 2017}}</ref> Top intelligence officials told them they "felt obligated to inform them about uncorroborated allegations about President-elect Donald Trump out of concern the information would become public and catch them off-guard".<ref name="Lederman_1/12/2017">{{cite web | last=Lederman | first=Josh | date=January 12, 2017 | title=Biden: Intel officials told us Trump allegations might leak | website=[[Associated Press]] | url=https://apnews.com/152579d488a740b2a8d39fbe2f34506d/biden-intel-officials-told-us-trump-allegations-might-leak | access-date=February 19, 2018}}</ref>
On January 11, 2017, ''[[Newsweek]]'' published a list of "13 things that don't add up" in the dossier, writing that it was a "strange mix of the amateur and the insightful" and stating that it "contains lots of Kremlin-related gossip that could indeed be, as the author claims, from deep insiders—or equally gleaned" from Russian newspapers and blogs.<ref name="Matthews_1/11/2017">{{cite web |last=Matthews |first=Owen |url=https://europe.newsweek.com/donald-trump-vladimir-putin-russia-intelligence-dossier-hacking-541626?rm=eu |title=Thirteen things that don't add up in the Russia-Trump intelligence dossier |date=January 11, 2017 |newspaper=[[Newsweek]] |access-date=February 1, 2017}}</ref> Former UK ambassador to Russia Sir [[Tony Brenton]] stated that certain aspects of the dossier were inconsistent with British intelligence's understanding of how the Kremlin works, commenting: "I've seen quite a lot of intelligence on Russia, and there are some things in [the dossier] which look pretty shaky."<ref name="SkyNews_1/13/2017">{{cite web|url=https://news.sky.com/story/trump-dossier-shaky-ex-british-envoy-to-russia-says-10726703|title=Trump dossier 'shaky', former British envoy to Russia says|date=January 13, 2017|website=[[Sky News]]|accessdate=February 28, 2017|quote=A former ambassador to Moscow casts doubts over elements of the report, as friends of the UK spy behind it leap to his defence.}}</ref>
In his June 2017 Senate Intelligence Committee testimony, former FBI director [[James Comey]] called "some personally sensitive aspects" of the dossier "salacious and unverified," but he did not state that the entire dossier was unverified or that the salacious aspects were false. When Senator Richard Burr asked if any of the allegations in the dossier had been confirmed, Comey said he could not answer that question in a public setting.<ref name="Comey_6/8/2017">{{cite web | last=Comey | first=James | url=https://www.cnn.com/2017/06/07/politics/james-comey-memos-testimony/index.html| title=James Comey's prepared testimony | publisher=[[CNN]]| date=June 8, 2017 | accessdate=January 1, 2018 }}</ref><ref name="Berke_6/8/2017"/>
Trump and his supporters have challenged the veracity of the dossier because it was funded in part by the Clinton campaign and the DNC, while Democrats assert the funding source is irrelevant.<ref name="Vogel_10_25_2017">{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/25/us/politics/steele-dossier-trump-expained.html | title=The Trump Dossier: What We Know and Who Paid for It | first=Kenneth P. | last=Vogel | date=October 25, 2017 | work=[[The New York Times]] | accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref>
=== Veracity of certain allegations === ==== Russian assistance to the Trump campaign ====
{{main|Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections|Trump Tower meeting}} A [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections#January 2017 Intelligence Community Assessment|January 6, 2017, intelligence community assessment]] released by the [[Office of the Director of National Intelligence]] (ODNI) stated that Russian leadership favored the Trump candidacy over Clinton's, and that Putin personally ordered an "influence campaign" to harm Clinton's electoral chances and "undermine public faith in the US democratic process," as well as ordering cyber attacks on "both major U.S. political parties".<ref name="ODNI_1/6/2017">{{cite report |author=ODNI |title=Background to 'Assessing Russian Activities and Intentions in Recent US Elections': The Analytic Process and Cyber Incident Attribution |url=https://www.dni.gov/files/documents/ICA_2017_01.pdf |date=January 6, 2017 |publisher=[[Office of the Director of National Intelligence]] | access-date=April 1, 2018}}</ref>
''[[Newsweek]]'' stated that "the dossier's main finding, that Russia tried to prop up Trump over Clinton, was confirmed by" this assessment.<ref name="Price_12/21/2017" /> [[ABC News]] stated that "some of the dossier's broad implications—particularly that Russian President Vladimir Putin launched an operation to boost Trump and sow discord within the U.S. and abroad—now ring true."<ref name="Levine_1/12/2018" /> Referring to the ODNI assessment, former ''Los Angeles Times'' Moscow correspondent Robert Gillette wrote in an op-ed in the ''[[Concord Monitor]]'' that the dossier has had at least one of its main factual assertions verified ... Steele's dossier, paraphrasing multiple sources, reported precisely the same conclusion, in greater detail, six months earlier, in a memo dated June 20."<ref name="Gillette_1/27/2017">{{cite web |title=My Turn: Inside the Trump dossier |website=[[Concord Monitor]] |date=January 27, 2017 |first=Robert |last=Gillette |url=https://www.concordmonitor.com/Trump-and-the-Russia-connection-part-one-7646273 |access-date=February 19, 2018}}</ref>
In ''[[The New Yorker]]'', Jane Mayer has stated that the allegation that Trump was favored by the Kremlin, and that they offered Trump's campaign dirt on Clinton, has proven true.<ref name="Mayer_3/12/2018"/>
In March 2016, [[George Papadopoulos]], a Trump campaign foreign policy adviser, learned that the Russians had "dirt" on Clinton in the form of thousands of stolen emails. This occurred before the hacking of the DNC computers had become public knowledge.<ref name="Kelly_11/13/2017">{{cite web| last=Kelly | first=Meg | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/fact-checker/wp/2017/11/13/all-of-the-known-times-the-trump-campaign-met-with-russians | title=All the known times the Trump campaign met with Russians | date=November 13, 2017 | website=[[The Washington Post]] | access-date=March 6, 2018 }}</ref><ref name="LaFraniere_Mazzetti_Apuzzo_12/30/2017">{{cite news | last=LaFraniere | first=Sharon | last2=Mazzetti | first2=Mark | last3=Apuzzo | first3=Matt | title=How the Russia Inquiry Began: A Campaign Aide, Drinks and Talk of Political Dirt | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=December 30, 2017 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/30/us/politics/how-fbi-russia-investigation-began-george-papadopoulos.html | access-date=January 21, 2018 }}</ref> Papadopoulos sent emails about Putin to at least seven Trump campaign officials. Trump national campaign co-chairman [[Sam Clovis]]<ref name="Helderman_11/2/2017">{{cite news |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=November 2, 2017 |first=Rosalind S. |last=Helderman |title=Who's who in the George Papadopoulos court documents |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/whos-who-in-the-george-papadopoulos-court-documents/2017/10/30/e131158c-bdb3-11e7-97d9-bdab5a0ab381_story.html | access-date=April 1, 2018}}</ref> encouraged Papadopoulos to fly to Russia and meet with agents of the [[Russian Foreign Ministry]], who reportedly wanted to share "Clinton dirt" with the Trump campaign.<ref name="Winter_Connor_Dilanian_Ainsley_10/30/2017">{{cite news |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/trump-campaign-adviser-george-papadopoulos-pleads-guilty-lying-n815596 |title=Secret Guilty Plea of Ex-Trump Campaign Adviser George Papadopoulos Reveals Russian Ties |first=Tom |last=Winter |first2=Tracy |last2=Connor |first3=Ken |last3=Dilanian |first4=Julia |last4=Ainsley |website=[[NBC News]] |date=October 30, 2017 |accessdate=October 30, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Apuzzo_Schmidt_10/30/2017">{{cite news |first1=Matt |last1=Apuzzo | first2= Michael S. |last2=Schmidt |authorlink1=Matt Apuzzo |authorlink2=Michael S. Schmidt |title=Trump Campaign Adviser Met With Russian to Discuss 'Dirt' on Clinton |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=October 30, 2017 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/30/us/politics/george-papadopoulos-russia.html | access-date=April 1, 2018}}</ref> When Donald Trump Jr. learned of the offer, he welcomed it by responding: "If it's what you say, I love it..."<ref name="Mayer_3/12/2018"/> Later, on June 9, 2016, a [[Trump Tower meeting|meeting in Trump Tower]] was held, ostensibly for representatives from Russia to deliver that dirt on Clinton.<ref name="CNN_Staff_7/15/2017">{{cite news |author=CNN Staff |url=https://www.cnn.com/2017/07/14/politics/donald-trump-jr-meeting/index.html |title=Trump Tower Russia meeting: At least eight people in the room |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=July 15, 2017 |access-date=April 1, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Bertrand_8/31/2017">{{cite web | last=Bertrand | first=Natasha | date=August 31, 2017 | title=Manafort's notes from the Trump Tower Russia meeting reportedly mention political contributions and the RNC | website=[[Yahoo! Finance]] | url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/manaforts-notes-trump-tower-russia-192213764.html | access-date=September 1, 2017}}</ref>
At the [[2018 Russia–United States summit|July 2018 summit meeting]], Putin was asked if he had wanted Trump to win the 2016 election. He responded "Yes, I did. Yes, I did. Because he talked about bringing the U.S.-Russia relationship back to normal."<ref name="Friedman_7/17/2018">{{cite web | last=Friedman | first=Uri | title=The White House Transcript Is Missing the Most Explosive Part of the Trump–Putin Press Conference | website=[[The Atlantic]] | date=July 17, 2018 | url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2018/07/trump-putin-press-conference-transcript/565385/ | access-date=July 23, 2018}}</ref>
==== 'Golden showers' allegation ====
Regarding the "golden showers" allegation, [[Michael Isikoff]] and [[David Corn]] have stated that Steele's "faith in the sensational sex claim would fade over time.... As for the likelihood of the claim that prostitutes had urinated in Trump's presence, Steele would say to colleagues, 'It's 50-50'."<ref name="Isikoff_Corn_3/17/2018">{{cite web | last1=Isikoff | first1=Michael | last2=Corn | first2=David | date=March 17, 2018 | title=Russian Roulette: the real story behind the Steele dossier on Donald Trump | website=[[The Australian Financial Review]] | url=https://www.afr.com/lifestyle/arts-and-entertainment/books/russian-roulette-the-real-story-behind-the-steele-dossier-20180315-h0xj4g | accessdate=May 10, 2018 }}</ref>
James Comey has stated that, after his meetings with Trump, he changed his view and now thinks the salacious claims are possibly true.<ref name="Evening_Standard_6/22/2018"/>
British music publicist [[Rob Goldstone]] believes it was "unlikely" that Trump used prostitutes while he was in Moscow. He has stated that he accompanied Trump at the 2013 Miss Universe pageant, and claimed that Trump was in Moscow for 36 hours, and that he was with Trump for 31 out of those 36 hours. According to flight records, Trump was in Moscow for 37 hours, having landed in Moscow at around 3 p.m. on Friday<ref name="Helderman_9/22/2018">{{cite web | last=Helderman | first=Rosalind S. | title=How a British music publicist ended up in the middle of the Russia storm | website=[[The Washington Post]] | date=September 22, 2018 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/how-a-british-music-publicist-ended-up-in-the-middle-of-the-russia-storm/2018/09/21/d1449a40-ba83-11e8-a8aa-860695e7f3fc_story.html | access-date=September 23, 2018}}</ref> and leaving at 3:58 a.m. early Sunday morning.<ref name="Silver_4/23/2018"/>
==== Republican position on Russian conflict with Ukraine ====
The dossier alleges that "the Trump campaign agreed to minimize US opposition to Russia's incursions into Ukraine".<ref name="Bertrand_9/22/2017">{{cite web | last=Bertrand | first=Natasha | title=Former Trump adviser: I gave the campaign 'the chance to intervene' in controversial Ukraine platform change | website=[[Business Insider]] | date=September 22, 2017 | url=https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-russia-campaign-platform-rnc-jd-gordon-2017-9 | access-date=January 23, 2018}}</ref> Harding considers this allegation to have been confirmed by the actions of the Trump campaign: "This is precisely what happened at the Republican National Convention last July, when language on the US's commitment to Ukraine was mysteriously softened."<ref name="Harding_5/10/2017"/> In July 2016, the [[Republican National Convention]] made changes to the Republican Party's platform on Ukraine: initially the platform proposed providing "lethal weapons" to Ukraine, but the line was changed to "appropriate assistance". ''[[NPR]]'' reported, "Diana Denman, a Republican delegate who supported arming U.S. allies in Ukraine, has told people that Trump aide J.D. Gordon said at the Republican Convention in 2016 that Trump directed him to support weakening that position in the official platform."<ref name="Johnson_12/4/2017">{{cite web | last=Johnson | first=Carrie | title=2016 RNC Delegate: Trump Directed Change To Party Platform On Ukraine Support | website=[[NPR]] | date=December 4, 2017 | url=https://www.npr.org/2017/12/04/568310790/2016-rnc-delegate-trump-directed-change-to-party-platform-on-ukraine-support | access-date=January 23, 2018}}</ref> [[J. D. Gordon]], who was one of Trump's national security advisers during the campaign, said that he had advocated for changing language because that reflected what Trump had said.<ref name="Bertrand_2/11/2017"/><ref name="Murray_Acosta_Schleifer_3/4/2017">{{cite web |last1=Murray |first1=Sara |last2=Acosta |first2=Jim |last3=Schleifer |first3=Theodore |title=More Trump advisers disclose meetings with Russia's ambassador |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2017/03/02/politics/russia-donald-trump-meetings-ambassador/ |date=March 4, 2017 |accessdate=April 10, 2017 |website=[[CNN]] }}</ref> The Trump campaign does not appear to have intervened in any other platform deliberations aside from the language on Ukraine.<ref name="Mak_Corse_8/3/2016">{{cite news |url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/trump-campaign-changed-ukraine-platform-lied-about-it|title=Trump Campaign Changed Ukraine Platform, Lied About It |last1=Mak |first1=Tim |last2=Corse |first2=Alexa |date=August 3, 2016 |work=[[The Daily Beast]] |accessdate=March 3, 2018}}</ref>
In an interview on ''[[This Week (ABC TV series)|This Week]]'', Trump told [[George Stephanopoulos]] that people in his campaign were responsible for changing the GOP's platform stance on Ukraine, but that he was not personally involved.<ref name="ABC_Trump_Stephanopoulos_7/31/2016">{{cite web |title='This Week' Transcript: Donald Trump, Vice President Joe Biden, and Ret. Gen. John Allen |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/week-transcript-donald-trump-vice-president-joe-biden/story?id=41020870 |date=July 31, 2016 |publisher=[[ABC News]] |series=[[This Week (ABC TV series)|This Week]] |access-date=April 18, 2018 }}</ref>
Trump had formerly taken a hard line on Ukraine. He initially denounced Russia's annexation of Crimea as a "land grab" that "should never have happened", and called for a firmer U.S. response, saying "We should definitely be strong. We should definitely do sanctions." But after hiring Manafort his approach changed; he said he might recognize Crimea as Russian territory and might lift the sanctions against Russia.<ref name="Crowley_8/3/2016">{{cite news |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2016/08/trump-manafort-ukraine-crimea-russia-226573 |title=Trump changed views on Ukraine after hiring Manafort |last=Crowley |first=Michael |date=August 3, 2016 |work=[[Politico]] |accessdate=March 3, 2018}}</ref>
==== Relations with Europe and NATO ====
[[File:Vladimir Putin (2017-07-08) (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|right|[[Vladimir Putin]] (2017)]] The dossier alleges that as part of a ''quid pro quo'' agreement, "the TRUMP team had agreed… to raise US/NATO defense commitments in the Baltics and Eastern Europe to deflect attention away from Ukraine, a priority for PUTIN who needed to cauterise the subject."<ref name="Bertrand_1/15/2017"/> Aiko Stevenson, writing in ''The Huffington Post,'' noted that some of Trump's actions seem to align with "Putin's wish list", which "includes lifting sanctions on Russia, turning a blind eye towards its aggressive efforts in the Ukraine, and creating a divisive rift amongst western allies."<ref name="Stevenson_1/18/2017"/> During the campaign Trump "called Nato, the centrepiece of Transatlantic security 'obsolete', championed the disintegration of the EU, and said that he is open to lifting sanctions on Moscow."<ref name="Stevenson_1/18/2017">{{cite web |last=Stevenson |first=Aiko |title=President Trump: The Manchurian Candidate? |website=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=January 18, 2017 |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/aiko-stevenson/president-trump-the-manchurian-candidate_b_14236674.html |access-date=January 21, 2018}}</ref> Harding adds that Trump repeatedly "questioned whether US allies were paying enough into Nato coffers."<ref name="Harding_5/10/2017"/> [[Jeff Stein (author)|Jeff Stein]], writing in ''[[Newsweek]]'', described how "Trump's repeated attacks on NATO have...frustrated...allies ...[and] raised questions as to whether the president has been duped into facilitating Putin's long-range objective of undermining the European Union."<ref name="Stein_12/21/2017">{{cite web | last=Stein | first=Jeff | date=December 21, 2017 | title=Putin's Man in the White House? Real Trump Russia Scandal is Not Mere Collusion, U.S. Counterspies Say | website=[[Newsweek]] | url=https://www.newsweek.com/trump-putin-man-white-house-russia-investigation-scandal-moscow-kremlin-755321 | accessdate=March 9, 2018 }}</ref> Trump's appearances at meetings with allies, including NATO and G7, have frequently been antagonistic; according to the ''Los Angeles Times'', "The president's posture toward close allies has been increasingly and remarkably confrontational this year, especially in comparison to his more conciliatory approach to adversaries, including Russia and North Korea."<ref name="Stokols_7/11/2018">{{cite web | last=Stokols | first=Eli | title=Trump disrupts NATO summit with blasts at allies, especially Germany, and new defense spending demands | website=[[Los Angeles Times]] | date=July 11, 2018 | url=http://www.latimes.com/politics/la-na-pol-trump-nato-20180711-story.html | access-date=July 23, 2018}}</ref>
==== Lifting of sanctions ====
The dossier says that Page, claiming to speak with Trump's authority, had confirmed that Trump would lift the existing sanctions against Russia if he were elected president.<ref name="Withnall_Sengupta_1/12/2017"/> On December 29, 2016, during the transition period between the election and the inauguration, National Security Advisor designate Flynn spoke to Russian Ambassador [[Sergei Kislyak]], urging him not to retaliate for newly imposed sanctions; the Russians took his advice and did not retaliate.<ref name="Miller_Entous_Nakashima_2/2017">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/national-security-adviser-flynn-discussed-sanctions-with-russian-ambassador-despite-denials-officials-say/2017/02/09/f85b29d6-ee11-11e6-b4ff-ac2cf509efe5_story.html |title=National security adviser Flynn discussed sanctions with Russian ambassador, despite denials, officials say |first=Greg |last=Miller |first2=Adam |last2=Entous |first3=Ellen |last3=Nakashima |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] | date=February 10, 2017 | access-date=April 1, 2018}}</ref> Within days after the inauguration, new Trump administration officials ordered State Department staffers to develop proposals for immediately revoking the economic and other sanctions.<ref name="Isikoff_6/1/2017"/> One retired diplomat later said, "What was troubling about these stories is that suddenly I was hearing that we were preparing to rescind sanctions in exchange for, well, nothing."<ref name="Dilanian_3/4/2018">{{cite news |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/former-diplomats-trump-team-sought-lift-sanctions-russia-n767406 |title=Former Diplomats: Trump Team Sought to Lift Sanctions on Russia |last=Dilanian |first=Ken |date=June 1, 2017 |work=[[NBC News]] |accessdate=March 4, 2018}}</ref> The staffers alerted Congressional allies who took steps to codify the sanctions into law. The attempt to overturn the sanctions was abandoned after Flynn's conversation was revealed and Flynn resigned.<ref name="Isikoff_6/1/2017">{{cite news |url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/trump-administrations-secret-efforts-ease-russia-sanctions-fell-short-231301145.html |title=How the Trump administration's secret efforts to ease Russia sanctions fell short |last=Isikoff |first=Michael |date=June 1, 2017 |work=[[Yahoo! News]] |accessdate=March 4, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Sipher_9/6/2017"/> In August 2017, Congress passed a bipartisan bill to impose new sanctions on Russia. Trump reluctantly signed the bill, but then refused to implement it.<ref name="Porter_1/30/2018">{{cite news |url=https://www.newsweek.com/trump-refuses-impose-new-sanctions-russia-because-threats-are-enough-794831 |title=Trump refuses to impose new sanctions on Russia |last=Porter |first=Tom |date=January 30, 2018 |work=[[Newsweek]] |accessdate=March 4, 2018}}</ref>
==== Spy withdrawn from Russian embassy ====
The dossier alleges that a "{{sic|Russian diplomat Mikhail KULAGIN}}" participated in US election meddling, and was recalled to Moscow because Kremlin was concerned that his role in the meddling would be exposed. The BBC later reported that US officials in 2016 had identified Russian diplomat Mikhail Kalugin as a spy and that he was under surveillance, thus "verifying" a key claim in the dossier.<ref name="Wood_3/30/2017"/> Kalugin was the head of the economics section at the Russian embassy. He returned to Russia in August 2016.<ref name="Borger_10/7/2017"/> ''McClatchy'' reported that the FBI was investigating whether Kalugin played a role in the election interference. Kalugin has denied the allegations.<ref name="Borger_10/7/2017"/><ref name="Hall_Stone_Gordon-Goldstein_2/15/2017">{{cite web | last1=Hall | first1=Kevin G | last2=Stone | first2=Peter | last3=Gordon | first3=Greg | last4=Goldstein | first4=David | title=Russian diplomat under U.S. scrutiny in election meddling speaks | website=[[McClatchyDC]] | date=February 15, 2017 | url=https://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/nation-world/national/article132761149.html | access-date=January 27, 2018}}</ref>
==== Page meeting with Rosneft officials ====
Jane Mayer said that this part of the dossier seems true, even if the name of an official may have been wrong. Page's congressional testimony confirmed he held secret meetings with top Moscow and Rosneft officials, including talks about a payoff: "When Page was asked if a Rosneft executive had offered him a 'potential sale of a significant percentage of Rosneft,' Page said, 'He may have briefly mentioned it'."<ref name="Mayer_3/12/2018">{{cite web | last=Mayer | first=Jane | title=Christopher Steele, the Man Behind the Trump Dossier | website=[[The New Yorker]] | date=March 12, 2018 | url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2018/03/12/christopher-steele-the-man-behind-the-trump-dossier | access-date=March 6, 2018}}</ref>
On November 2, 2017, Page appeared before the [[House Intelligence Committee]] (HPSCI) which is investigating Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections. In July 2016, Page made a five-day trip to Moscow,<ref name="Prokop_2/2/2018">{{cite news | last=Prokop | first=Andrew | title=Carter Page, the star of the Nunes memo, explained | work=[[Vox (website)|Vox]] | date=February 2, 2018 | url= https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2018/2/2/16956014/nunes-memo-carter-page | access-date=April 13, 2018}}</ref> but, according to his testimony, before leaving he informed [[Jeff Sessions]], [[J. D. Gordon]], [[Hope Hicks]], and [[Corey Lewandowski]], Trump's campaign manager, of the planned trip to Russia, and Lewandowski approved the trip, responding: "If you'd like to go on your own, not affiliated with the campaign, you know, that's fine."<ref name="Tracy_11/7/2017"/><ref name="Raju_Herb_Polantz_11/8/2017">{{cite news |date=November 8, 2017 |first=Manu |last=Raju |first2=Jeremy |last2=Herb |first3=Katelyn |last3=Polantz |title=Carter Page reveals new contacts with Trump campaign, Russians |website=[[CNN]] |url=https://www.cnn.com/2017/11/06/politics/carter-page-testimony-released/index.html | access-date=April 1, 2018}}</ref> In his testimony, Page admitted he met with high ranking Kremlin officials. Previously, Page had denied meeting any Russian officials during the July trip. His comments appeared to corroborate portions of the dossier.<ref name="Lanktree_11/7/2017"/><ref name="Kelly_11/6/2017"/> ''[[Newsweek]]'' has listed the claim about Page meeting with Rosneft officials as "verified".<ref name="Maza_1/10/2018">{{cite news |url=https://www.newsweek.com/trump-russia-dossier-one-year-later-what-we-know-777116 |title=How true is the Trump-Russia dossier? One year later, what we know about its claims. |last=Maza |first=Cristina |date=January 10, 2018 |work=[[Newsweek]] |accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref>
== Investigations using or referencing the dossier == === The FBI's Russia investigation ===
{{main|Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections}} In late July 2016, "the CIA had set up a special group with the NSA and FBI... to investigate the extent of Russian intervention in the presidential election." Former CIA director [[John O. Brennan|John Brennan]] then "ensured that all information about links between the Trump campaign and people working for or on behalf of Russian intelligence went to the FBI."<ref name="Borger_5/23/2017">{{cite web | last=Borger | first=Julian | title=Ex-CIA chief: Trump staff had enough contact with Russia to justify FBI inquiry | website=[[The Guardian]] | date=May 23, 2017 | url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/may/23/ex-cia-chief-john-brennan-concerns-russian-ties-trump-team | access-date=April 25, 2018}}</ref> These [[links between Trump associates and Russian officials]] were numerous. ''[[Politico]]'' keeps a very detailed running tally of the persons, and, as of April 25, 2018, they listed "73 associated with [Trump's] 2016 campaign".<ref name="Samuelsohn_Frostenson_Lin_Samuelsohn_1/21/2018">{{cite web | last=Samuelsohn | first=Darren | last2=Frostenson | first2=Sarah | last3=Lin | first3=Jeremy C.F. | last4=Samuelsohn | first4=Darren | last5=Frostenson | first5=Sarah | last6=Lin | first6=Jeremy C.F. | title=The 285 people connected to the Russia probes | website=[[Politico]] | date=January 21, 2018 | url=https://www.politico.com/interactives/2018/trump-russia-investigation-ties/ | access-date=April 25, 2018}}</ref> [[Julian Borger]] reported that in Brennan's testimony before the House intelligence committee, he made it clear "that he was alarmed by the extent of contacts between the Trump team and Moscow," and that this justified the FBI inquiry:<ref name="Borger_5/23/2017"/>
{{quotebox|width=30em|Brennan stressed repeatedly that collusion may have been unwitting, at least at first as Russian intelligence was deft at disguising its approaches to would-be agents. "Frequently, individuals on a treasonous path do not even realize they're on that path until it gets to be too late," he said.<ref name="Borger_5/23/2017"/>}}
The investigation was also spurred by comments made by Trump foreign policy adviser [[George Papadopoulos]].<ref name="LaFraniere_Mazzetti_Apuzzo_12/30/2017"/><ref name="Hart_12/30/2017"/> While Trump and some Republicans have claimed that the dossier was behind the beginning of the FBI investigation into his campaign's potential conspiracy with Russia, in December 2017, former and current intelligence officials revealed that the actual impetus was a series of comments made in May 2016 by Papadopoulos to [[Alexander Downer]], a top Australian diplomat, during a night of "heavy drinking at an upscale London bar".<ref name="Hart_12/30/2017"/><ref name="LaFraniere_Mazzetti_Apuzzo_12/30/2017"/> [[Shep Smith]], an anchor at ''[[Fox News]]'', confirmed this series of events, directly contradicting Trump's and [[Sean Hannity]]'s false claims that the dossier was the impetus for the start of the investigation.<ref name="Hutzler_8//16/2018"/> John Sipher reported that Papadopoulos bragged "that the Trump campaign was aware the Russian government had dirt on Hillary Clinton"<ref name="Sipher_1/11/2018">{{cite web | last=Sipher | first=John | date=January 11, 2018 | title=What Should We Make of The Dirty Dossier at the Heart of the Mueller Investigation? | website=[[Newsweek]] | url=https://www.newsweek.com/what-should-we-make-dirty-dossier-heart-mueller-investigation-778496 | accessdate=May 11, 2018 }}</ref> in the form of "thousands of emails" stolen from Clinton which could be used to damage her campaign. Papadopoulos had learned this about three weeks earlier. Two months later, when WikiLeaks started releasing DNC emails, Australian officials alerted the Americans about Papadopoulos' remarks.<ref name="Hart_12/30/2017">{{cite web |last=Hart |first=Benjamin |title=Report: Papadopoulos, Not Dossier, Sparked Russia Investigation |website=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] |date=December 30, 2017 |url=https://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2017/12/report-papadopoulos-sparked-russia-investigation.html |access-date=December 31, 2017}}</ref><ref name="LaFraniere_Mazzetti_Apuzzo_12/30/2017"/> Over a year later, Papadopoulos was arrested on July 27, 2017,<ref name="Wang_Wilkie_10/30/2017">{{cite web | last=Wang | first=Christine | last2=Wilkie | first2=Christina | title=Ex-Trump advisor George Papadopoulos pleaded guilty to lying to FBI agents, authorities reveal | website=[[CNBC]] | date=October 30, 2017 | url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/10/30/ex-trump-adviser-papadopolous-pleaded-guilty-to-lying-to-fbi-agents.html | access-date=May 13, 2018}}</ref> and in October 2017, Papadopoulos pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI, and became a cooperating witness in Mueller's investigation.<ref name="Hart_12/30/2017"/><ref name="Wang_Wilkie_10/30/2017"/>
Other factors also played into the FBI's decision to investigate Russian interference and the Trump campaign: intelligence from friendly governments, especially the British and Dutch, and information about Page's Moscow trip. Steele's first report was sent to Fusion GPS, dated June 20, 2016, and FBI agents first interviewed Steele in October 2016.<ref name="LaFraniere_Mazzetti_Apuzzo_12/30/2017"/> ''The New York Times'' reported on February 14, 2017, that the FBI had made contact with some of Steele's sources.<ref name="Schmidt_Mazzetti_Apuzzo_2/14/2017">{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/14/us/politics/russia-intelligence-communications-trump.html |title=Trump Campaign Aides Had Repeated Contacts With Russian Intelligence |first1=Michael S. |last1=Schmidt |first2=Mark |last2=Mazzetti |first3=Matt |last3=Apuzzo |date=February 14, 2017 |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=April 27, 2018}}</ref> CNN later reported that the FBI had used the dossier to bolster its existing investigations.<ref name="Borger_4/28/2017"/><ref name="Perez_Prokupecz_Raju_4/18/2017"/>
In a January 2, 2018, CNN panel discussion, [[Elizabeth Price Foley|Elizabeth Foley]], a [[Florida International University]] law professor, falsely alleged that the FISA warrant for Page was "all based on a dossier", adding "That's what Jim Comey has suggested." She also cited reports from CNN and ''The New York Times''. [[PolitiFact]] concluded that her claim about Comey was unsubstantiated, and according to CNN, the dossier was only "part of the justification", and that ''The New York Times'' report did not mention the dossier. PolitiFact rated her claim "Mostly False".<ref name="Graves_1/5/2018">{{cite web | last=Graves | first=Allison | title=Taking a closer look at the 'Steele dossier' | website=[[PolitiFact]] | date=January 5, 2018 | url=https://www.politifact.com/florida/statements/2018/jan/05/elizabeth-foley/taking-closer-look-steele-dossier-and-carter-pages/}}</ref>
The FBI has resisted [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|FOIA]] requests which would force it to reveal classified details of its investigation, including its efforts to disprove or confirm allegations in the dossier. This resistance has been approved by U.S. District Court Judge [[Amit P. Mehta]], but a move by Trump to declassify some of this material, and a following FOIA lawsuit by journalist Josh Gerstein and a pro-transparency group, the James Madison Project, resulted in a ruling which would allow some declassification. The irony of the situation was noted by Brad Moss, a lawyer involved in that lawsuit: "It will be rather ironic if the president's peripheral actions that resulted in this ruling wind up disclosing that the FBI has been able to corroborate any of the 'salacious' allegations."<ref name="Gerstein_8/16/2018">{{cite web | last=Gerstein | first=Josh | title=Judge: Trump's release of dossier memos opens door to disclosures from FBI | website=[[Politico]] | date=August 16, 2018 | url=https://politi.co/2BjIzqh | access-date=August 18, 2018}}</ref>
On August 28, 2018, [[Bruce Ohr]], former head of the Justice Department's [[Organized Crime Drug Enforcement Task Force]], testified at a closed-door interview with Congressmen that he had "passed on 'dossier'-linked information to the FBI".<ref name="Levine_8/29/2018" /> At that time, the FBI's investigation had already been underway for four months, and the FBI had cited "previously-obtained information from the 'dossier'" to support secret surveillance of [[Carter Page]].<ref name="Levine_8/29/2018">{{cite web | last=Levine | first=Mike | title=The Russia probe: A timeline from Moscow to Mueller | website=[[ABC News]] | date=August 29, 2018 | url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/russia-probe-timeline-moscow-mueller/story?id=57427441 | access-date=August 30, 2018}}</ref> Contrary to a [[conspiracy theory]] promoted by Trump, there is no evidence that Ohr was involved in the start of the Russia probe.<ref name="Shear_Benner_Fandos_8/17/2018">{{Cite news | first1=Michael D. |last1=Shear |first2=Katie |last2=Benner |first3=Nicholas |last3=Fandos | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/17/us/politics/trump-conspiracy-bruce-nellie-ohr.html | title=Embracing Conspiracy Theory, Trump Escalates Attack on Bruce Ohr | date=August 17, 2018 | newspaper=[[The New York Times]] }}</ref> According to a congressional source speaking to [[ABC News]], Ohr had "little impact" on the investigation.<ref name="Levine_8/23/2018">{{Cite web | last=Levine | first=Mike | url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/doj-bosses-bruce-ohr-offered-russia-probe-sources/story?id=57367588 | title=He went around his DOJ bosses, but Bruce Ohr offered little to Russia probe, sources say | date=August 23, 2018 | publisher=[[ABC News]] }}</ref>
On September 1, 2018, congressional sources relayed to the [[Associated Press]] that Ohr told members of Congress he had met Steele over breakfast on July 30, 2016, along with Nellie Ohr and a Steele associate. At that time Steele revealed that he had been told Russian intelligence believed "they had Trump [[wikt:over a barrel|over a barrel]]", an assertion that Steele echoed in his dossier. Ohr also stated that Steele told him Page had met with "higher-level Russian officials than [he] had acknowledged".<ref name="Tucker_Day_9/1/2018">{{cite web | last=Tucker | first=Eric | last2=Day | first2=Chad | title=AP sources: Lawyer was told Russia had 'Trump over a barrel' | agency=[[Associated Press]] | date=September 1, 2018 | url=https://apnews.com/4ac772445073491aa7d3ca9e558e0144/AP:-Justice-lawyer-was-told-Russia-had-%27Trump-over-a-barrel | access-date=September 1, 2018}}</ref>
In July 2018, after the FBI released redacted FISA court documents related to Carter Page, former federal prosecutor [[Andrew C. McCarthy]] wrote in ''[[National Review]]'' that the documents show that the FBI's [[probable cause]] finding that Trump campaign adviser Page conspired with Russian government to influence the 2016 election was based on the dossier. McCarthy said that even though each of the four surveillance applications claimed that the FBI had "verified" Steele's information, the bureau did not confirm the allegations independent of Steele. He also said that if the allegations had been corroborated, "the bureau would not be suffering in silence" and if the FBI and Justice Department had solid evidence to verify the dossier's allegations, which were based on multiple hearsay, they "would have used that evidence as their probable cause showing against Page".<ref>{{cite news |last1=McCarthy |first1=Andrew C. |authorlink1=Andrew C. McCarthy |title=FISA Applications Confirm: The FBI Relied on the Unverified Steele Dossier |url=https://www.nationalreview.com/2018/07/carter-page-fisa-applications-fbi-steele-dossier/ |work=National Review |date=July 23, 2018}}</ref> Former federal prosecutors [[Barbara McQuade]], Daniel S. Goldman, and Mimi Rocah said that McCarthy argued on Fox News and in his column that: "(1) the so-called Steele dossier was 'the driving force behind the Trump-Russia investigation'; (2) the FISA court was not told that the Clinton campaign was behind Steele's work; and (3) the FBI did not 'verify' the factual allegations contained in the dossier." After quickly dismissing the first two arguments as unsupported, they turned their attention to the third point, explaining that such verification is not always possible, and that if every detail of an accusation must first be proven before an application for surveillance can be submitted, then much police work would never happen. They argue that hearsay evidence is allowable as part of a FISA submission. In this case, they assert that the "FBI would've been derelict not to use Steele dossier for the Carter Page FISA warrant". All the FBI had to prove was "probable cause", not the higher standard of "beyond a [[reasonable doubt]]": the "FISA application simply provided evidence that there was probable cause to believe that Carter Page was an agent of a foreign power and may have, or may be about to, commit violations of criminal law."<ref name="McQuade_Goldman_Rocah_7/25/2018">{{cite web|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/fbi-would-have-been-derelict-not-to-use-the-steele-dossier-for-the-carter-page-fisa-warrant|title=FBI Would've Been Derelict Not to Use Steele Dossier for the Carter Page FISA Warrant|last1=McQuade|first1=Barbara|last2=Goldman|first2=Daniel S.|date=July 25, 2018|website=[[The Daily Beast]]|access-date=August 19, 2018|last3=Rocah|first3=Mimi}}</ref>
=== Special counsel investigation ===
{{main|Special Counsel investigation (2017–present)}} According to [[Senate Intelligence Committee]] vice chairman [[Mark Warner]] (D-VA), the dossier's allegations are being investigated by a [[Special Counsel investigation (2017–present)|Special Counsel]] led by [[Robert Mueller]], which, since May 2017, has been investigating allegations of Russian interference in the 2016 elections.<ref name="Bertrand_10/5/2017"/> In the summer of 2017, Mueller's team of investigators met with Steele.<ref name="Perez_Prokupecz_Brown_10/25/2017">{{cite web |last1=Perez |first1=Evan |last2=Prokupecz |first2=Shimon |last3=Brown |first3=Pamela |url=https://www.cnn.com/2017/10/05/politics/special-counsel-russia-dossier-christopher-steele/index.html |title=Mueller's team met with Russia dossier author |website=[[CNN]] |date=October 25, 2017 |accessdate=November 5, 2017}}</ref> As some leads stemming from the dossier have already been followed and confirmed by the FBI, legal experts have stated that Special Counsel investigators, headed by Robert Mueller, are obligated to follow any leads the dossier has presented them with, irrespective of what parties financed it in its various stages of development, or "[t]hey would be derelict in their duty if they didn't."<ref name="Bertrand_10/5/2017">{{cite web |last=Bertrand |first=Natasha |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-russia-steele-dossier-investigations-2017-10 |title=Congressional and FBI investigators are homing in on the Trump–Russia dossier |work=[[Business Insider]] |date=October 5, 2017 |accessdate=November 6, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Feldman_11/2/2017">{{cite web |last=Feldman |first=Kate |url=https://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/hillary-clinton-defends-funding-steele-dossier-trump-russia-article-1.3605464 |title=Hillary Clinton defends funding Steele dossier on Trump, Russia |work=[[New York Daily News]] |date=November 2, 2017 |accessdate=November 6, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Bertrand_10/26/2017">{{cite web | last=Bertrand | first=Natasha | title=Former DOJ, FBI officials: Mueller has 'an obligation' to examine the Trump-Russia dossier | website=[[Business Insider]] | date=October 26, 2017 | url=https://www.businessinsider.com/steele-dossier-trump-russia-mueller-investigation-2017-10 | access-date=October 6, 2018}}</ref>
=== Subject of the Nunes memo ===
{{main|Nunes memo}} On February 2, 2018, the Nunes memo, a four-page memorandum written for [[U.S. Representative]] [[Devin Nunes]] by his staff, was released to the public. Referring to the dossier, the memo states that the FBI "may have relied on politically motivated or questionable sources" to obtain a [[United States Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court#FISA warrant|Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) warrant]] in October 2016 and in three subsequent renewals on Carter Page in the early phases of the FBI's interference investigation.<ref name="Parker_Helderman_Dawsey_Leonnig_1/27/2018">{{Cite news |last=Parker |first=Ashley |last2=Helderman |first2=Rosalind S. |last3=Dawsey |first3=Josh |last4=Leonnig |first4=Carol D. |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-sought-release-of-classified-russia-memo-putting-him-at-odds-with-justice-department/2018/01/27/a00f2a4c-02bb-11e8-9d31-d72cf78dbeee_story.html |title=Trump sought release of classified Russia memo, putting him at odds with Justice Department |date=January 27, 2018 |work=[[The Washington Post]] |access-date=January 29, 2018}}</ref> Republican legislators argued that the memo presents evidence that a group of politically-biased FBI employees abused the FISA warrant process for the purpose of undermining the [[Presidency of Donald Trump|Trump presidency]].<ref name="Savage_1/30/2018">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/30/us/politics/secret-memo-mueller-russia-investigation.html |title=The Real Aim of the Nunes Memo Is the Mueller Investigation |last=Savage |first=Charlie |date=January 30, 2018 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=April 1, 2018}}</ref> The Nunes memo stated that there was excessive and improper dependence on the Trump–Russia dossier.
On February 3, 2018, Trump praised the Nunes memo and tweeted: {{tweet|block=yes|text=This memo totally vindicates "Trump" in probe. But the Russian Witch Hunt goes on and on. Their was no Collusion and there was no Obstruction (the word now used because, after one year of looking endlessly and finding NOTHING, collusion is dead). This is an American disgrace!|date=3 Feb 2018|name=Donald J. Trump|username=realDonaldTrump|id=959798743842349056 | access-date=April 1, 2018}}
Rep. [[Trey Gowdy]] (R-S.C.) disagreed, stating on February 4 on CBS's ''[[Face the Nation]]'': "I actually don't think [the memo] has any impact on the Russia probe." He went on to say:
{{quote|"There is a Russia investigation without a dossier," Gowdy said. "So to the extent the memo deals with the dossier and the FISA process, the dossier has nothing to do with the meeting at Trump Tower. The dossier has nothing to do with an email sent by Cambridge Analytica. The dossier really has nothing to do with George Papadopoulos' meeting in Great Britain. It also doesn't have anything to do with obstruction of justice. So there's going to be a Russia probe, even without a dossier."<ref name="Robertson_2/7/2018"/> }}
Gowdy was dissatisfied with the process of seeking the warrant: "I say investigate everything Russia did but admit that this was a really sloppy process that you engaged in to surveil a U.S. citizen." When questioned, he said that the FISA warrant on Carter Page would not have been authorized without the dossier.<ref name="Watson_2/4/2018">{{cite web | last=Watson | first=Kathryn | title=Gowdy says surveillance warrant would not have been authorized without dossier | website=[[CBS News]] | date=February 4, 2018 | url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/trey-gowdy-face-the-nation-fisa-surveillance-warrant-would-not-have-been-authorized-without-dossier/ | access-date=April 30, 2018}}</ref>
Jane Mayer has quoted Democratic Senator [[Sheldon Whitehouse]]: "To impeach Steele's dossier is to impeach Mueller's investigation... It's to recast the focus back on Hillary", with the Republicans' aim to "create a false narrative saying this is all a political witch hunt." Mayer tied his view directly to [[Devin Nunes]]' production of "a report purporting to show that the real conspiracy revolved around Hillary Clinton," falsely alleging that Clinton "colluded with the Russians...", a claim debunked by [[Glenn Kessler (journalist)|Glenn Kessler]].<ref name="Mayer_3/12/2018"/> Kessler, a [[fact checking|fact checker]] for ''The Washington Post'', analyzed a false accusation made by Nunes in a February 7, 2018, interview on the [[Hugh Hewitt Show]]: "The truth is that they [Democrats] are covering up that Hillary Clinton colluded with the Russians to get dirt on Trump to feed it to the FBI to open up an investigation into the other campaign." Kessler's "[[Pinocchio]] Test" rating was: "[T]here is no evidence that Clinton was involved in Steele's reports or worked with Russian entities to feed information to Steele.
