That's where Nunes's claim goes off the rails—and why he earns Four Pinocchios."<ref name="Kessler_2/9/2018">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/fact-checker/wp/2018/02/09/did-hillary-clinton-collude-with-the-russians-to-get-dirt-on-trump-to-feed-it-to-the-fbi/|title=Did Hillary Clinton collude with the Russians to get 'dirt' on Trump to feed it to the FBI?|last=Kessler|first=Glenn|date=February 9, 2018|website=[[The Washington Post]]|access-date=February 12, 2018}}</ref> "Four Pinocchios" equals a "Whopper".<ref name="Kessler_9/11/2013">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/fact-checker/about-the-fact-checker/|title=About The Fact Checker|last=Kessler|first=Glenn|date=September 11, 2013|website=[[The Washington Post]]|access-date=February 13, 2018}}</ref>
The Nunes memo falsely asserted that "Comey briefed President-elect Trump on a summary of the Steele dossier, even though it was—according to his June 2017 testimony—'salacious and unverified.'" Factcheckers noted that Comey actually testified that "some personally sensitive aspects of the information" were "salacious and unverified," rather than the entire dossier.<ref name="Jacobson_2/5/2018">{{cite web | last=Jacobson | first=Louis | title=Nunes memo twists James Comey's words on Steele dossier | website=[[PolitiFact]] | date=February 5, 2018 | url=https://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2018/feb/05/devin-nunes/nunes-memo-twists-james-comeys-words-steele-dossie/ | access-date=April 23, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Kiely_6/7/2017">{{cite web | last=Kiely | first=Eugene | title=Timeline of Russia Investigation | website=[[FactCheck]] | date=June 7, 2017 | url=https://www.factcheck.org/2017/06/timeline-russia-investigation/ | access-date=April 24, 2018}}</ref> The Nunes memo asserted that [[Andrew McCabe]] testified to the House Intelligence Committee that "no surveillance warrant [of [[Carter Page]]] would have been sought from the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court (FISC) without the Steele dossier information," but because McCabe testified in classified session, no transcript has yet been released to verify this assertion. In a CNN interview, McCabe asserted "that House Republicans twisted his answers":
{{quote|"We started the investigations without the dossier. We were proceeding with the investigations before we ever received that information.... Was the dossier material important to the package? Of course, it was. As was every fact included in that package. Was it the majority of what was in the package? Absolutely not."<ref name="Brown_Jarrett_3/17/2018">{{cite web | last=Brown | first=Pamela | last2=Jarrett | first2=Laura | title=McCabe says Republicans 'mischaracterized' his testimony on Trump dossier | website=[[CNN]] | date=March 17, 2018 | url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/03/16/politics/mccabe-republicans-trump-dossier/index.html | access-date=April 24, 2018}}</ref>}}
Congressman [[Eric Swalwell]], a member of the Committee, also stated that McCabe's testimony was mischaracterized.<ref name="Hains_2/2/2018">{{cite web | last=Hains | first=Tim | url=https://www.realclearpolitics.com/video/2018/02/02/rep_swalwell_nunes_memo_misquotes_mccabes_statement_about_steele_dossierfisa_warrant.html | date=February 2, 2018 | title=Rep. Swalwell: Nunes Memo Misquotes McCabe's Statement About Steele Dossier/FISA Warrant | website=[[RealClearPolitics]] | accessdate=April 23, 2018}}</ref>
Contrary to assertions by Trump and his supporters that the FBI investigation into [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]] was triggered by the dossier,<ref name="Cassidy_2/2/2018">{{cite web | last=Cassidy | first=John | title=The Nunes Memo Undermines the Right's Trump-Russia Conspiracy Theory | website=[[The New Yorker]] | date=February 2, 2018 | url=https://www.newyorker.com/news/our-columnists/the-nunes-memo-undermines-the-rights-trump-russia-conspiracy-theory | access-date=April 29, 2018}}</ref> the Nunes memo confirmed the investigation began with a tip from Australian diplomat [[Alexander Downer]] regarding a conversation he had with Trump foreign policy adviser [[George Papadopoulos]] in a London bar in May 2016.<ref name="LaFraniere_Mazzetti_Apuzzo_12/30/2017"/><ref name="Lucas_2/2/2018">{{cite web | last=Lucas | first=Ryan | url=https://www.npr.org/2018/02/02/582713363/memo-russian-overtures-to-trump-aide-triggered-fbi-investigation | date=February 2, 2018 | title=Nunes Memo: What's In It And What's Not | publisher=[[NPR]] | accessdate=April 23, 2018}}</ref> The FBI opened its investigation in late July 2016, and ''The Washington Post'' noted that this timing is "significant, given the FBI did not seek authorization to conduct surveillance on Page until three months later, on Oct. 21, 2016." The Democrats asserted that the Nunes memo "shows the Russia investigation would be underway with or without the surveillance of Page, and—more critically—even if the government had never seen the dossier of information about Trump that was compiled by Christopher Steele, a former British spy."<ref name="Tumulty_Helderman_2/2/2018">{{cite web | last=Tumulty | first=Karen | last2=Helderman | first2=Rosalind S. | title=Sentence buried in GOP memo may undercut Trump efforts to discredit Russia probe | website=[[The Washington Post]] | date=February 2, 2018 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/sentence-buried-in-gop-memo-may-undercut-trump-efforts-to-discredit-russia-probe/2018/02/02/4133ebe4-0846-11e8-b48c-b07fea957bd5_story.html | access-date=April 30, 2018}}</ref>
Amid assertions in the Nunes memo and from others that the dossier's use in the Carter Page FISA warrant request was improper—countered by Democrats' assertions that there was nothing improper—on April 6, 2018, the Justice Department made the FISA application available for all members of the House and Senate Intelligence Committees to review.<ref name="Jarrett_4/7/2018">{{cite web | last=Jarrett | first=Laura | title=Justice to let all intelligence panel members see Carter Page surveillance application | website=[[CNN]] | date=April 7, 2018 | url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/04/06/politics/justice-carter-page-surveillance-application/index.html | access-date=April 28, 2018}}</ref>
On July 21, 2018, the Justice Department released heavily redacted versions of four FISA warrant applications for Carter Page which, according to [[Pulitzer Prize]]-winning New York Times reporter, [[Charlie Savage]], showed that key assertions made in the Nunes memo were "misleading or false", corroborating the rebuttal made by Democrats.<ref name="Savage_7/22/2018">{{cite web | last=Savage |first=Charlie | title=How a Trump Decision Revealed a G.O.P. Memo's Shaky Foundation | website=[[The New York Times]] | date=July 22, 2018 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/22/us/politics/how-a-trump-decision-revealed-a-gop-memos-shaky-foundation.html | access-date=July 30, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Kris_7/21/2018">{{cite web | last=Kris | first=David |title=What to Make of the Carter Page FISA Applications | url=https://www.lawfareblog.com/what-make-carter-page-fisa-applications | work=[[Lawfare (blog)|Lawfare]] | date=July 21, 2018 | access-date=July 23, 2018}}</ref>

=== Donald Trump ===
Donald Trump has repeatedly condemned the dossier and denied collusion with Russia, including in this tweet, in which he quotes from ''[[Fox & Friends]]'':<ref name="Lee_12/26/2017"/>
{{tweet|block=yes|text=WOW, @foxandfrlends "Dossier is bogus. Clinton Campaign, DNC funded Dossier. FBI CANNOT (after all of this time) VERIFY CLAIMS IN DOSSIER OF RUSSIA/TRUMP COLLUSION. FBI TAINTED." And they used this Crooked Hillary pile of garbage as the basis for going after the Trump Campaign!|date=26 Dec 2017|name=Donald J. Trump|username=realDonaldTrump|id=945646491955290113 | access-date=June 1, 2018}}
Trump has called the dossier "[[Fake news#Usage of the term by Donald Trump|fake news]]" and criticized the intelligence and media sources that published it.<ref name="Henderson_Lawler_Burke_1/12/2017">{{cite web |last1=Henderson |first1=Barney |last2=Lawler |first2=David |last3=Burke |first3=Louise |title=Donald Trump attacks alleged Russian dossier as 'fake news' and slams Buzzfeed and CNN at press conference |website=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=January 12, 2017 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/01/11/donald-trump-kremlin-blast-fabricated-report-russian-ties-asfbi/ |access-date=February 19, 2018}}</ref> During a press conference on January 11, 2017, Trump denounced the dossier's claims as false, saying that it was "disgraceful" for U.S. intelligence agencies to report them.<ref name="Rascoe_1/11/2017">{{cite web |last=Rascoe |first=Ayesha |title=Trump accuses U.S. spy agencies of Nazi practices over 'phony' Russia dossier |website=[[Reuters]] |date=January 11, 2017 |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump/russia-likely-main-topic-in-trumps-first-news-conference-since-election-idUSKBN14V18L |access-date=February 19, 2018}}</ref> Trump refused to take a question from CNN's senior White House correspondent [[Jim Acosta]] on the subject. In response, CNN said that it had published "carefully sourced reporting" on the matter which had been "matched by the other major news organizations", as opposed to [[BuzzFeed]]'s posting of "unsubstantiated claims".<ref name="Sutton_1/11/2017">{{cite web |last1=Sutton |first1=Kelsey |date=January 11, 2017 |title=Trump calls CNN 'fake news', as channel defends its reporting on intelligence briefing |url=https://www.politico.com/blogs/on-media/2017/01/trump-refusing-to-answer-question-from-cnn-reporter-you-are-fake-news-233485 |website=[[Politico]] |accessdate=January 11, 2017}}</ref>
On October 25, 2017, ''The Wall Street Journal'' reported that the DNC and Clinton campaign paid a total of $12.4 million to Perkins Coie for legal and compliance services during the 2016 campaign.<ref>Full access to WSJ article via Twitter: https://twitter.com/WSJeurope/status/923205592038158337</ref> On October 29, 2017, Trump tweeted that the dossier had cost $12 million.<ref name="Hosenball_11/1/2017"/><ref name="Trump_10/29/2017">{{cite web | last=Trump | first=Donald J. | title=Donald J. Trump on Twitter | website=[[Twitter]] | date=October 29, 2017 | url=https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/924635359480303616 | access-date=September 9, 2018 | quote="Never seen such Republican ANGER & UNITY as I have concerning the lack of investigation on Clinton made Fake Dossier (now $12,000,000?),...." }}</ref>
Three days later, on November 1, 2017, Fusion GPS revealed to [[Reuters]] that they had informed Congress{{when|date=October 2018}} that Perkins Coie had paid them $1.02 million in fees and expenses, $168,000 of which was paid by Fusion GPS to Steele's firm, Orbis Business Intelligence, and used by Orbis to produce the dossier.<ref name="Hosenball_11/1/2017"/>
Multiple journalists noted that Trump did not provide evidence for his claim that the dossier cost $12 million, and that it in fact cost far less.<ref name="Hosenball_11/1/2017"/><ref name="Price_11/2/2017">{{cite web | last=Price | first=Greg | title=Trump's Golden Shower Dossier Cost Nowhere Near as Much as He Claimed on Twitter | date=November 2, 2017 | website=[[Newsweek]] | url=https://www.newsweek.com/trump-dossier-cost-millions-699816 | access-date=September 9, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Khan_11/2/2017">{{cite web | last=Khan | first=Shehab | title=Former British spy paid more than £125,000 to detail Donald Trump Russia links | website=[[MSN]] | date=November 2, 2017 | url=https://www.msn.com/en-gb/news/world/former-british-spy-paid-more-than-%C2%A3125000-to-detail-donald-trump-russia-links/ar-AAukWi7 | access-date=September 9, 2018}}</ref>
As late as September 6, 2018, Trump still claimed that Steele was paid "millions of dollars" for his work.<ref name="Bump_9/6/2018">{{cite web | last=Bump | first=Philip | title=Trump's declassifying what now? | website=[[The Washington Post]] | date=September 6, 2018 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2018/09/06/trumps-declassifying-what-now/ | access-date=September 7, 2018}}</ref> On October 11, 2018, [[Donald Trump Jr.]] repeated his father's claim by tweeting that Clinton's "campaign and the DNC spent over $12,000,000.00 working with foreign agents to creat [sic] a fake dossier with them."<ref name="Edelman_10/12/2018">{{cite web | last=Edelman | first=Adam | title=Clinton strikes back at Trump for saying she colluded with Russia | website=[[NBC News]] | date=October 12, 2018 | url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/hillary-clinton/clinton-strikes-back-trump-after-he-charged-she-colluded-russia-n919566 | access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref>
=== Other responses ===
[[James Clapper]] described the leaks as damaging to U.S. national security.<ref name="Hartmann_1/12/2017">{{cite web |last1=Hartmann |first1=Margaret |date=January 12, 2017 |title=Clapper Denounces 'Corrosive and Damaging' Trump Dossier Leak |url=https://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2017/01/clapper-denounces-corrosive-damaging-trump-dossier-leak.html |website=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] |accessdate=January 12, 2017}}</ref> This contradicted Trump's previous claim that Clapper had said the information was false; Clapper's statement actually said the intelligence community had made no judgment on the truth of the information.<ref name="Weisman_Steinhauer_1/12/2017">{{cite news |last1=Weisman |first1=Jonathan |last2=Steinhauer |first2=Jennifer |title=Intelligence Chief's Olive Branch to Trump Gets Twisted in Translation |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/12/us/politics/donald-trump-transition.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=January 12, 2017 | access-date=April 1, 2018}}</ref>
As Putin's press secretary, Peskov insisted in an interview that the dossier is a fraud, saying "I can assure you that the allegations in this funny paper, in this so-called report, they are untrue. They are all fake."<ref name="Neely_1/21/2017">{{cite news |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/putin-spokesman-u-s-intelligence-report-russian-hacking-ridiculous-n706096 |title=Kremlin Spokesman: U.S. Intelligence Report on Russian Hacking 'Ridiculous' |last=Neely |first=Bill |date=January 21, 2017 |work=[[NBC News]] |accessdate=January 15, 2017}}</ref> Putin called the people who leaked the dossier "worse than prostitutes"<ref name="Fox_Putin_1/17/2017">{{cite news|url=https://www.foxnews.com/politics/2017/01/17/putin-those-who-leaked-trump-dossier-worse-than-prostitutes.html|title=Putin: Those who leaked Trump dossier 'worse than prostitutes'|date=January 17, 2017|work=[[Fox News]]|access-date=January 17, 2017}}</ref> and referred to the dossier itself as "rubbish".<ref name="Dewan_Veselinovic_1/17/2017">{{cite news |url=https://www.cnn.com/2017/01/17/politics/russia-us-putin-trump/index.html |title=Putin on Trump dossier claims: 'Rubbish' |first=Angela |last=Dewan |first2=Milena |last2=Veselinovic |work=[[CNN]] | date=January 17, 2017 | access-date=January 17, 2017}}</ref> Putin went on to state he believed that the dossier was "clearly fake",<ref name="Macfarquhar_1/17/2017">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/17/world/europe/putin-trump-memo.html |title=Putin Says Accusations in Trump Dossier Are 'Clearly Fake' |last=Macfarquhar |first=Neil |date=January 17, 2017 |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=January 18, 2017}}</ref> fabricated as a plot against the legitimacy of President-elect Trump.<ref name="Roth_Filipov_1/17/2017">{{cite 19, 2018}}</ref>
Some of Steele's former colleagues expressed support for his character, saying "The idea his work is fake or a cowboy operation is false—completely untrue. Chris is an experienced and highly regarded professional. He's not the sort of person who will simply pass on gossip."<ref name="Harding_Hopkins_1/12/2017">{{cite web | last=Harding | first=Luke | last2=Hopkins | first2=Nick | title=Donald Trump dossier: intelligence sources vouch for author's credibility | website=[[The Guardian]] | date=January 12, 2017 | url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jan/12/intelligence-sources-vouch-credibility-donald-trump-russia-dossier-author | access-date=January 23, 2018}}</ref>
Among journalists, [[Bob Woodward]] called the dossier a "garbage document", while [[Carl Bernstein]]<!-- Bernstein's comments are visible when the whole article is opened. --> took the opposite view, noting that the senior-most U.S. intelligence officials had determined that the content was worth reporting to the president and the president-elect.<ref name="Fox_News_garbage_1/16/2017">{{cite web |author=Fox News |title='Garbage Document': Woodward Says US Intel Should Apologize Over Trump Dossier | website=[[Fox News]] | date=January 16, 2017 | url=https://insider.foxnews.com/2017/01/16/garbage-document-woodward-says-trump-owed-apology-over-unverified-russia-dossier | access-date=February 19, 2018}}</ref> [[Julian Borger]] has described the dossier as "one of the most explosive documents in modern political history..."<ref name="Borger_10/7/2017"/> [[Ben Smith (journalist)|Ben Smith]], editor of BuzzFeed, wrote: "The dossier is a document...of obvious central public importance. It's the subject of multiple investigations by intelligence agencies, by Congress. That was clear a year ago. It's a lot clearer now."<ref name="Greenwood_1/10/2018">{{cite web |last=Greenwood |first=Max |title=BuzzFeed editor defends publication of dossier |website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] | date=January 10, 2018 |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/media/368442-buzzfeed-editor-defends-publication-of-dossier |access-date=March 31, 2018}}</ref>
[[Ynet]], an Israeli online news site, reported on January 12, 2017, that U.S. intelligence advised Israeli intelligence officers to be cautious about sharing information with the incoming Trump administration, until the possibility of Russian influence over Trump, suggested by Steele's report, has been fully investigated.<ref name="Bergman_1/12/2017">{{cite web |first=Ronen |last=Bergman |url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4906642,00.html |title=US intel sources warn Israel against sharing secrets with Trump administration |work=[[Ynetnews]] |date=January 12, 2017 | access-date=April 1, 2018}}</ref>
On March 2, 2017, media began reporting that the Senate may call Steele to testify about the Trump dossier.<ref name="Hunt_Dilanian_3/2/2017">{{cite web |last=Hunt |first=Kasie |last2=Dilanian |first2=Ken |title=The Senate may call Christopher Steele to testify about Trump dossier |website=[[NBC News]] |date=March 2, 2017 |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/senate-may-question-ex-british-spy-who-compiled-trump-dossier-n728371 | access-date=April 1, 2018}}</ref> On March 27, 2017, SJC Chairman [[Chuck Grassley]] |last=Ross |first=Brian |last2=Mosk |first2=Matthew |last3=Schwartz |first3=Rhonda |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/glenn-simpson-key-figure-million-dollar-dossier-face/story?id=49348102 |title=Glenn Simpson key figure behind million-dollar dossier to face questions |date=August 22, 2017 |website=[[ABC News]] |accessdate=August 23, 2017}}</ref>
[[Stephen Holmes (CIA)|Steven L. Hall]], former CIA chief of Russia operations, has contrasted Steele's methods with those of [[Donald Trump Jr.]], who sought information from a Russian attorney at a [[Trump Tower meeting|meeting in Trump Tower in June 2016]]: "The distinction: Steele spied against Russia to get info Russia did not want released; Don Jr took a mtg to get info Russians wanted to give."<ref name="Carter_10/27/2017">{{cite web |last=Carter |first=Brandon |title=CIA's ex-Russia chief: Unlike Steele, Trump Jr. took info Russia wanted to give |website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |date=October 27, 2017 |url=https://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/357602-ex-cia-russia-chief-unlike-trump-dossier-russia-wanted-to-give |access-date=December 27, 2017}}</ref>
[[Jane Mayer]] referred to the same meeting and contrasted the difference in reactions to Russian attempts to support Trump: When Trump Jr. was offered "dirt" on Clinton as "part of Russia and its government's support for Mr. Trump," instead of "going to the F.B.I., as Steele had" done when he learned that Russia was helping Trump, Trump's son accepted the support by responding: "If it's what you say, I love it..."<ref name="Mayer_3/12/2018"/>
On January 2, 2018, Simpson and Fritsch authored an op-ed in ''The New York Times'', requesting that Republicans "release full transcripts of our firm's testimony" and further wrote that, "the Steele dossier was not the trigger for the FBI's investigation into Russian meddling. As we told the Senate Judiciary Committee in August, our sources said the dossier was taken so seriously because it corroborated reports the bureau had received from other sources, including one inside the Trump camp."<ref name="Simpson_Fritsch_1/2/2018">{{cite news | last1=Simpson | first1=Glenn R. | last2=Fritsch | first2=Peter | title=The Republicans' Fake investigations | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=January 2, 2018 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/02/opinion/republicans-investigation-fusion-gps.html | access-date=January 3, 2018}}</ref> Ken Dilanian of NBC News stated that a "source close to Fusion GPS" told him that the FBI had not planted anyone in the Trump camp, but rather that Simpson was referring to Papadopoulos.<ref name="Shafer_1/13/2018">{{cite web |last=Shafer |first=Jack |title=Week 34: The Dossier Strikes Back |website=[[Politico]] |date=January 13, 2018 |url=https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2018/01/13/jack-shafer-swamp-diary-trump-dossier-216313 |access-date=January 21, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Jalonick_1/9/2018"/>
On January 4, 2018, U.S. District Court Judge Amit P. Mehta ruled on Trump's repeated tweets describing the dossier as "fake" or "discredited":
{{quote|"None of the tweets inescapably lead to the inference that the President's statements about the Dossier are rooted in information he received from the law enforcement and intelligence communities ... The President's statements may very well be based on media reports or his own personal knowledge, or could simply be viewed as political statements intended to counter media accounts about the Russia investigation, rather than assertions of pure fact."<ref name="Gerstein_1/4/2018">{{cite web | last=Gerstein | first=Josh | title=Judge: Trump tweets don't require more disclosure on dossier | website=[[Politico]] | date=January 4, 2018 | url=http://politi.co/2Ar3OR4 | access-date=August 18, 2018}}</ref>}}

Justice Department suggesting that they investigate possible criminal charges against Steele<ref name="Stanglin_1/5/2018">{{cite web | last=Stanglin | first=Doug | title=GOP senators recommend url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/senior-republican-refers-trump-dossier-author-for-possible-charges/2018/01/05/ead4585e-f0af-11e7-b390-a36dc3fa2842_story.html | work=[[The Washington Post]] And I'm talking about the literal shredding of the U.S. Constitution."<ref name="Fernandez_2/5/2018">{{cite web | last=Fernandez | first=Nick | title=The Nunes memo perfectly lined up with what Hannity has been hyping for weeks prior to its release | website=[[Media Matters for America]] | date=February 5, 2018 | url=https://www.mediamatters.org/research/2018/02/05/nunes-memo-perfectly-lined-what-hannity-has-been-hyping-weeks-prior-its-release/219276 | access-date=April 25, 2018}}</ref>
On January 18, 2018, the HPSCI released the transcript of the Simpson Testimony given on November 14, 2017.<ref name="Chamberlain_1/18/2018">{{cite news |last=Chamberlain |first=Samuel |url=https://www.foxnews.com/politics/2018/01/18/house-panel-releases-glenn-simpson-testimony-transcript.html |title=House panel releases Glenn Simpson testimony transcript |date=January 18, 2018 |work=[[Fox News]] | access-date=April 1, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Singman_1/18/2018">{{Cite news |url=https://www.foxnews.com/politics/2018/01/18/house-intelligence-committee-votes-to-release-transcript-interview-with-fusion-gps-boss.html |title=House Intelligence Committee votes to release transcript of interview with Fusion GPS boss |last=Singman |first=Brooke |date=January 18, 2018 |work=[[Fox News]] |access-date=January 19, 2018}}</ref> Democratic committee member [[Adam Schiff]] stated that the testimony contains "serious allegations that [[The Trump Organization]] may have engaged in money laundering with Russian nationals". Democratic member [[Jim Himes]] said that Simpson "did not provide evidence and I think that's an important point. Schiff |date=January 18, 2018 |website=[[Reuters]] |access-date=April 1, 2018}}</ref>
In April 2018, the [[White House Correspondents' Association]] (WHCA) gave [[White House Correspondents' Association#The Merriman Smith Memorial Award|The Merriman Smith Memorial Award]] to CNN reporters Evan Perez, [[Jim Sciutto]], [[Jake Tapper]] and [[Carl Bernstein]]. In January 2017, they reported that the intelligence community had briefed Obama and Trump of allegations that Russians claimed to have "compromising personal and financial information" on then-President elect Donald Trump.<ref name="Perez_Sciutto_Tapper_Bernstein_1/10/2017"/><ref name="Calderone_4/2/2018">{{cite news |last1=Calderone |first1=Michael |title=Trump's correspondents' dinner decision gets complicated |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/04/02/trump-journalists-correspondents-dinner-495858 |work=[[Politico]] |date=April 2, 2018 |access-date=April 8, 2018}}</ref> WHCA noted that "[t]hanks to this CNN investigation, 'the dossier' is now part of the lexicon".<ref name="WHCA_4/2/2018">{{cite web|url=https://www.whca.net/awards.htm|title=White House Correspondents' Association, journalism awards for 2018|author=|first=|date=April 2, 2018|website=[[White House Correspondents' Association]]|access-date=April 3, 2018}}</ref>
As late as July 29, 2018, Trump continued to falsely insist that the FBI investigation of Russian interference was initiated because of the dossier, and three days later White House press secretary [[Sarah Sanders]] repeated the false assertion. Fox News host [[Shepard Smith]] said of Trump's assertion: "In the main and in its parts, that statement is patently false."<ref name="Dicker_8/1/2018">{{cite web | last=Dicker | first=Rachel | date=August 1, 2018 | title=Fox News' Shepard Smith Calls Out Trump, White House for Claim About Russia Probe: 'Patently False' | website=[[Mediaite]] | url=https://www.mediaite.com/tv/fox-news-shepard-smith-calls-out-trump-white-house-for-claim-about-russia-probe-patently-false/ | accessdate=August 1, 2018 }}</ref>
===Circumstances surrounding the death of Oleg Erovinkin===
On December 26, 2016, [[Oleg Erovinkin]], a former [[KGB]]/[[Federal Security Service|FSB]] general, was found dead in his car in Moscow. Erovinkin was a key liaison between Sechin and Putin. Steele claimed much of the information came from a source close to Sechin. According to Christo Grozev, a journalist at Risk Management Lab, a [[think tank]] based in Bulgaria, the circumstances of Erovinkin's death were "mysterious". Grozev suspected Erovinkin helped Steele compile the dossier on Trump and suggests the hypothesis that the death may have been part of a cover-up by the Russian government.<ref name="Mendick_Verkaik_1/27/2017">{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/01/27/mystery-death-ex-kgb-chief-linked-mi6-spys-dossier-donald-trump/ |title=Mystery death of ex-KGB chief linked to MI6 spy's dossier on Donald Trump |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |first=Robert |last=Mendick |first2=Robert |last2=Verkaik |date=January 27, 2017 |access-date=January 31, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Zois_1/28/2017">{{cite web |url=https://www.aol.com/article/news/2017/01/28/russians-suspected-of-aiding-investigations-into-hacking-are-being-arrested-possibly-murdered/21702243/ |title=Russians suspected of aiding investigations into hacking are being arrested and possibly murdered |last=Zois |first=Chris |date=January 28, 2017 |publisher=[[AOL]] |access-date=January 31, 2017}}</ref> Experts expressed skepticism about the theory. "As a rule, people like Gen Yerovinkin don't tend to die in airport thriller murders," said [[Mark Galeotti]], an expert on the Russian security services.<ref name="Mendick_Verkaik_1/27/2017"/>
=== Litigation === ==== Against BuzzFeed and Fusion GPS ====
On February 3, 2017, Aleksej Gubarev, chief of technology company XBT and a figure mentioned in the dossier, sued BuzzFeed for defamation. The suit, filed in a [[Broward County, Florida]] court, centers on allegations from the dossier that XBT had been "using [[botnet]]s and porn traffic to transmit viruses, plant bugs, steal data and conduct 'altering operations' against the Democratic Party leadership".<ref name="Goldstein_Hall_Gordon_2/3/2017">{{cite web |last1=Goldstein |first1=David |last2=Hall |first2=Kevin G. |last3=Gordon |first3=Greg |title=BuzzFeed sued over its publication of uncorroborated Trump dossier |url=https://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/politics-government/article130659399.html |work=[[McClatchyDC]] |date=February 3, 2017 |access-date=April 1, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Rosenberg_2/4/2017">{{cite news |last1=Rosenberg |first1=Eli |title=Russian Executive Sues BuzzFeed Over Unverified Trump Dossier |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/04/us/russia-trump-buzzfeed-sue.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=February 4, 2017 | access-date=April 1, 2018}}</ref> In the [[High Court of Justice]], Steele's lawyers said their client did not intend for the memos to be released, and that one of the memos "needed to be analyzed and further investigated/verified".<ref name="Cohen_5/2/2017">{{cite web |last=Cohen |first=Marshall |url=https://www.cnn.com/2017/05/02/politics/donald-trump-spy-dossier/index.html |title=Spy behind Trump dossier says info was never meant for public eyes |date=May 2, 2017 |website=[[CNN]] |accessdate=May 3, 2017}}</ref> In response to the lawsuit, BuzzFeed hired the business advisory firm [[FTI Consulting]] to investigate the dossier's allegations.<ref name="Winter_2/12/2018">{{cite news |last=Winter |first=Jana |url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2018/02/12/former-senior-fbi-official-is-leading-buzzfeeds-effort-to-verify-trump-dossier/ |title=Former Senior FBI Official Is Leading BuzzFeed's Effort to Verify Trump Dossier |work=[[Foreign Policy]] |date=February 12, 2018 |accessdate=February 13, 2018}}</ref> BuzzFeed has sued the DNC in an attempt to force the disclosure of information it believes will bolster its defense against libel allegations.<ref name="Pompeo_2/13/2018">{{cite news |url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2018/02/buzzfeed-dnc-lawsuit-russia-dossier |quote=Now, BuzzFeed is taking the Democratic National Committee to court in an attempt to compel it to turn over information it believes will bolster its defense against Aleksej Gubarev, a Russian business magnate who says he was libeled in the dossier when it tied him to the Russians' alleged hacking of the D.N.C.'s e-mail servers. In a nutshell: BuzzFeed believes the D.N.C. has information that could show a link between Gubarev and the e-mail hacking, which would undercut his libel claim. |work=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]] |title=BuzzFeed Is Suing the D.N.C. Over Issues Involving the Russia Dossier |first=Joe |last=Pompeo |date=February 13, 2018 |access-date=February 14, 2018}}</ref> Fusion GPS "has claimed that it did not provide the dossier to BuzzFeed."<ref name="MSN_10/11/2017">{{cite web |author=MSN | title=Trump-Russia Dossier Plot Thickens | website=[[MSN]] | date=October 11, 2017 | url=https://a.msn.com/05/en-ph/AAtj9QP | access-date=March 31, 2018}}</ref>
In connection with the libel suit against them by Gubarev, on June 30, 2017, BuzzFeed subpoenaed the CIA, the FBI, and the Office of the Director of National Intelligence. They also sought "testimony from fired FBI Director James Comey, as well as former DNI James Clapper and CIA Director John Brennan". They were interested in using the [[discovery (law)|discovery process]] to get information about the distribution of the dossier, how it had circulated among government officials, and the "existence and scope of the federal government's investigation into the dossier". They hoped "the information could bolster BuzzFeed's claim that publication of the document was protected by the fair report privilege, which can immunize reports based on official government records."<ref name="Gerstein_6/30/2017">{{cite web | last=Gerstein | first=Josh | title=BuzzFeed subpoenas feds for Trump dossier info | website=[[Politico]] | date=June 30, 2017 | url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/06/30/buzzfeed-trump-russia-dossier-subpoena-240146 | access-date=April 22, 2018}}</ref> On June 4, 2018, Judge [[Ursula Ungaro]] ruled that BuzzFeed could claim "fair report privilege" for the publication of the dossier and its accompanying article, bolstering BuzzFeed's defense.<ref name="Gerstein_6/4/2018">{{cite web | last=Gerstein | first=Josh | title=Judge in libel suit rules BuzzFeed may have protection for report on Trump dossier | website=[[Politico]] | date=June 4, 2018 | url=https://politi.co/2sFwMuR | access-date=June 6, 2018}}</ref>
Cyber security and intelligence expert Andrew Weisburd has stated that both Gubarev and the dossier "can be right": "Their explanation is entirely plausible, as is the Steele Dossier's description of Mr. Gubarev as essentially a victim of predatory officers of one or more Russian intelligence services.... Neither BuzzFeed nor Steele have accused Gubarev of being a willing participant in wrongdoing."<ref name="Hall_9/21/2018"/>
In May 2017, [[Mikhail Fridman]], [[Petr Aven]], and [[German Khan]] – the owners of [[Alfa-Bank|Alfa Bank]] – filed a defamation lawsuit against BuzzFeed for publishing the unverified dossier,<ref name="Porter_5/27/2017">{{cite news |last=Porter |first=Tom |title=Russian Bankers Sue BuzzFeed Over Publication Of Unverified Trump Dossier |url=https://www.newsweek.com/alfa-bank-buzzfeed-trump-dossier-616763 |work=[[Newsweek]] |date=May 27, 2017 |accessdate=May 28, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Gerstein_5/26/2017">{{cite news |last1=Gerstein |first1=Josh |title=Russian bank owners sue BuzzFeed over Trump dossier publication |url=https://www.politico.com/blogs/under-the-radar/2017/05/26/trump-dossier-russian-bank-owners-sue-buzzfeed-238876 |work=[[Politico]] |date=May 26, 2017 |accessdate=May 28, 2017}}</ref> which alleges financial ties and collusion between Putin, Trump, and the three bank owners.<ref name="Smith_1/11/2017">{{cite news |last=Smith |first=Geoffrey |title=Here's Why Russian Intelligence Bombshell on Donald Trump Might Be Believable |url=https://fortune.com/2017/01/11/donald-trump-intelligence-russian/ |work=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] |date=January 11, 2017 |accessdate=April 5, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Sommer_1/11/2017">{{cite news |last=Sommer |first=Allison Kaplan |title=Controversial Dossier on Trump Alleges That Russia Targets Jewish-American Businessmen |url=https://www.haaretz.com/us-news/leaked-trump-dossier-alleges-that-russia-targets-jewish-americans-1.5484596 |work=[[Haaretz]] |date=January 11, 2017 |accessdate=April 5, 2018}}</ref> In October 2017, Fridman, Aven, and Khan also filed a libel suit against Fusion GPS and Glenn Simpson, for circulating the dossier among journalists and allowing it to be published.<ref name="Gerstein_10/4/2017">{{cite news |last=Gerstein |first=Josh |title=3 Russians named in Trump dossier sue Fusion GPS for libel |url=https://www.politico.com/blogs/under-the-radar/2017/10/04/trump-dossier-fusion-gps-russians-lawsuit-fridman-aven-khan-243461 |work=[[Politico]] |date=October 4, 2017 |accessdate=March 29, 2018}}</ref>
On January 9, 2018, Michael Cohen sued BuzzFeed and Fusion GPS for [[defamation]] over allegations about him in the dossier.<ref name="Jacobs_1/9/2018">{{Cite news |last=Jacobs |first=Jennifer |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-01-10/trump-lawyer-cohen-sues-buzzfeed-over-claims-in-russia-dossier |title=Trump Lawyer Sues BuzzFeed, Fusion GPS on Russia Dossier Claims |date=January 9, 2018 |work=[[Bloomberg News]] |access-date=January 16, 2018 |quote=Cohen said he's mentioned in the dossier 15 times.}}</ref> On April 19, 2018, ten days after his home, office and hotel room were raided by the FBI as part of a criminal investigation, Cohen filed a motion to voluntarily dismiss the suit.<ref name="Gerstein_4/19/2018">{{Cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/04/19/michael-cohen-drops-buzzfeed-fusion-lawsuit-537327|title=Cohen drops libel suits against BuzzFeed, Fusion GPS|last=Gerstein|first=Josh|date=April 19, 2018|work=[[Politico]]|access-date=April 19, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Abbruzzese_4/19/2018">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/trump-lawyer-michael-cohen-drops-lawsuit-against-buzzfeed-over-steele-n867406|title=Trump lawyer Michael Cohen drops lawsuit against BuzzFeed over Steele dossier|last=Abbruzzese|first=Jason|date=April 19, 2018|work=[[NBC News]]|access-date=April 19, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name="Strobel_Walcott_4/9/2018">{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-cohen-raid/fbi-raids-offices-home-of-trumps-personal-lawyer-sources-idUSKBN1HG336|title=FBI raids offices, home of Trump's personal lawyer: sources|last=Strobel|first=Warren|last2=Walcott|first2=John|date=April 9, 2018|work=[[Reuters]]|access-date=April 19, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref>
==== Against Christopher Steele ====
On April 16, 2018, Alfa Bank owners Fridman, Aven, and Khan filed a libel suit against Steele and Orbis Business Intelligence,<ref name="Polantz_4/20/2018">{{cite news |last=Polantz |first=Katelyn |title=3 Russian oligarchs sue Christopher Steele |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/04/20/politics/oligarchs-lawsuit-christopher-steele/index.html |work=[[CNN]] |date=April 20, 2018 |accessdate=April 22, 2018}}</ref> since the dossier alleges financial ties and collusion between Putin, Trump, and the three bank owners.<ref name="Smith_1/11/2017"/><ref name="Sommer_1/11/2017"/> The lawsuit was filed in Washington D.C.<ref name="Polantz_4/20/2018"/> Steele's lawyers filed two motions to dismiss the case, accusing the three men of intimidation.<ref name="Haynes_6/7/2018">{{cite web | last=Haynes | first=Deborah | date=June 7, 2018 | title=Former spy Christopher Steele attacks Russians in Trump dossier case | website=[[The Times]] | url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/former-spy-christopher-steele-attacks-russians-in-trump-dossier-case-zqnr2d9bd | accessdate=June 7, 2018 }}</ref>
On August 20, 2018, a judge in the [[Superior Court of the District of Columbia]] threw out the libel suit. The case was [[dismissed with prejudice]] in response to a motion by lawyers for Orbis Business Intelligence.<ref name="Maddow_8/20/2018">{{cite web | last=Maddow | first=Rachel | title=Russia's Alfa Bank fails in lawsuit over Steele's Trump dossier | url=https://www.msnbc.com/rachel-maddow/watch/russia-s-alfa-bank-fails-in-lawsuit-over-steele-s-trump-dossier-1303085635995 | website=[[MSNBC]] | series=''[[The Rachel Maddow Show]]'' | type=video | date=August 20, 2018 | access-date=August 20, 2018}}</ref> Without assessing whether the dossier was "accurate or not accurate", the judge determined that the dossier was covered by the [[First Amendment]], which protects [[freedom of speech]]. He also pointed out its importance to the public interest: "The Steele dossier generated so much interest and attention in the US precisely because its contents relate to active public debates here."<ref name="Harding_8/21/2018">{{cite web | last=Harding | first=Luke | title=Author of Trump-Russia dossier wins libel case in US court | website=[[The Guardian]] | date=August 21, 2018 | url=http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/aug/21/author-of-trump-russia-dossier-wins-libel-case-in-us-court-christopher-steele | access-date=August 23, 2018}}</ref>
==== Against DNC and Perkins Coie ====
On October 15, 2018, it was reported that Carter Page has sued the DNC, Perkins Coie, "as well as a few of the firm's partners", for defamation.<ref name="Burke_10/15/2018">{{cite web | last=Burke | first=Michael | title=Carter Page files defamation lawsuit against DNC | website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] | date=October 15, 2018 | url=https://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/411556-carter-page-files-defamation-lawsuit-against-dnc | access-date=October 17, 2018}}</ref>
